{{NHLTeamSeason |League=NHL |Season=1990–91 |year=1990 |Team=Calgary Flames |Conference=[[Western Conference (NHL)|Campbell]] |ConferenceRank=4th |Division=[[Smythe Division|Smythe]] |DivisionRank=2nd |Record=46–26–8 |HomeRecord=29–8–3 |RoadRecord=17–18–5 |GoalsFor=344 (1st) |GoalsAgainst=263 (6th) |GeneralManager=[[Cliff Fletcher]] |Coach=[[Doug Risebrough]] |Captain=Rotating |AltCaptain=Rotating |Arena=[[Pengrowth Saddledome|Olympic Saddledome]] |Attendance=19,986 |GoalsLeader=[[Theoren Fleury]] (51) |AssistsLeader=[[Al MacInnis]] (75) |PointsLeader=Theoren Fleury (104) |PIMLeader=[[Gary Roberts (ice hockey)|Gary Roberts]] (252) |WinsLeader=[[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]] (31) |GAALeader=[[Rick Wamsley]] (3.05) }} The '''[[1990–91 NHL season|1990–91]] [[Calgary Flames]] season''' was the [[Calgary Flames seasons|11th]] [[National Hockey League]] [[season (sports)|season]] in [[Calgary]]. The Flames entered the season with a new coach, as they replaced [[Terry Crisp]] with [[Doug Risebrough]]. Crisp coached 277 games with the Flames over three years, and his .669 regular season winning percentage remains a Flames record.Head Coaches, ''2006–07 Calgary Flames media guide'', pg. 103 The [[Los Angeles Kings]] ended the Flames three-year run at the top of the [[Smythe Division]] standings, finishing two points ahead of Calgary. The Flames finished 4th overall in the NHL1990–91 season, ''2006–07 Calgary Flames media guide'', pg. 121 Calgary's 344 goals led the NHL, the second time the Flames led the league in scoring. In the playoffs, Calgary met the defending champion [[Edmonton Oilers]] in the first round. Despite finishing 20 points ahead of Edmonton, the Flames fell to the Oilers in seven games. Four Flames represented the [[Campbell Conference]] at the [[42nd National Hockey League All-Star Game|1991 All-Star Game]]: forward [[Theoren Fleury]], defencemen [[Al MacInnis]] and [[Gary Suter]] and goaltender [[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]]. Additionally, MacInnis was named to the [[NHL All-Star Team|First All-Star team]] for the second season in a row.All-Stars, ''2006–07 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', pg. 22 Fleury's 51 goals tied him for 2nd in league scoring, behind [[Brett Hull]]'s 86. Fleury (104) and MacInnis (103) placed 8th and 9th respectively in league point scoring, with MacInnis leading the league in scoring by a defenceman. MacInnis also placed 3rd in the league in assists.[http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/leaders/nhl19271991.html 1990–91 league leaders], hockeydb.com In an 8-4 Flames' road win over the St. Louis Blues on March 9, 1991, Theoren Fleury scored three short-handed goals.https://www.hockey-reference.com/boxscores/199103090STL.html {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Regular season== For the second consecutive season, the Flames led the league in scoring (344 goals for), power-play goals scored (91: tied with the [[New York Rangers]]) and power-play percentage, with 23.70% (91 for 384).https://www.hockey-reference.com/leagues/NHL_1991.html ===Season standings=== {{1990–91 NHL Smythe Division standings |team=CAL}} {{1990–91 NHL Campbell Conference standings|team=CAL}} ==Schedule || Los Angeles || 3 – 5 || Calgary || || 46–26–8 || 100 |} |} ==Playoffs== The Flames met their arch-rivals, the defending [[Stanley Cup]] champion [[Edmonton Oilers]] in the first round of the playoffs. Despite finishing 20 points ahead of Edmonton in the regular season, the Flames fell to the Oilers in seven games. Calgary's game six victory featured Theoren Fleury's memorable dash down the length of the ice following his overtime winning goal. {{As of|2015}}, it was the last time the two rivals met in the playoffs. {| class="toccolours" width=90% style="clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan=11 style="background:#FFC859" | [[1991 Stanley Cup Playoffs]] |- | colspan=11 | {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" width=100% align="center" |- ! colspan=11; bgcolor=#E17E7E|Smythe Division semi-final vs. Edmonton |- align="center" bgcolor="#dddddd" | '''Game''' || '''Date''' || '''Visitor''' || '''Score''' || '''Home''' || '''OT''' || '''Attendance''' || '''Series''' |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 1 || April 4 || Edmonton || 3 – 1 || Calgary || || 20,176 || Edmonton leads 1–0 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 2 || April 6 || Edmonton || 1 – 3 || Calgary || || 20,176 || Series tied 1–1 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 3 || April 8 || Calgary || 3 – 4 || Edmonton || || 17,242 || Edmonton leads 2–1 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 4 || April 10 || Calgary || 2 – 5 || Edmonton || || 17,503 || Edmonton leads 3–1 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 5 || April 12 || Edmonton || 3 – 5 || Calgary || || 20,176 || Edmonton leads 3–2 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 6 || April 14 || Calgary || 2 – 1 || Edmonton || OT || 17,503 || Series tied 3–3 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 7 || April 16 || Edmonton || 5 – 4 || Calgary || OT || 20,176 || Edmonton wins 4–3 |} |} ==Player statistics== ===Skaters=== ''Note: GP = Games played; G = Goals; A = Assists; Pts = Points; PIM = Penalty Minutes'' {| BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="3" CELLSPACING="2" ID="Table1" |- ALIGN="center" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" ! revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} References to English [[cricket]] matches in the [[1727 English cricket season|1727 season]] between the [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|2nd Duke of Richmond]] and Mr [[Alan Brodrick, 2nd Viscount Midleton|Alan Brodrick]] mention that they drew up '''Articles of Agreement''' between them to determine the rules that must apply in their contests. This may be the first time that rules were formally agreed, although rules as such definitely existed. In early times, the rules would be agreed orally and subject to local variations.<ref name=LTL/>
==The Articles==
[[Articles of Agreement]] by and between [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|his Grace the Duke of Richmond]] & [[Alan Brodrick, 2nd Viscount Midleton|Mr. Brodrick]] for two [[Cricket]] Matches concluded the Eleventh of July 1727:<ref name=LTL/>
* Imprimis 'Tis by the aforesaid Parties agreed that the first Match shall be played some day of this Instant July in the county of [[Surrey|Surry]] (''sic''); the Place to be named by Mr Brodrick; the second match to be played in August next in the County of [[Sussex]], the Place to be named by the Duke of Richmond. * 2d: That the wickets shall be pitched in a fair & even place, at twenty three yards distance from each other. * 3d: A Ball caught, cloathed or not cloathed, the Striker is out. * 4th: When a Ball is caught out, the Stroke counts nothing. * 5th: Catching out behind the Wicket allowed. * 6th: That 'tis lawfull (''sic'') for the Duke of Richmond to choose any Gamesters, who have played in either of His Grace's two last Matches with [[Sir William Gage, 7th Baronet|Sir William Gage]]; and that 'tis lawfull (''sic'') for Mr. Brodrick to choose any Gamesters within three Miles of [[Peper Harow|Pepperhara]], provided they actually lived there last [[Lady Day]]. * 7th: that twelve Gamesters shall play on each side. * 8th: that the Duke of Richmond & Mr. Brodrick shall determine the Ball or Balls to be played with. * 9th: if any of the Gamesters shall be taken lame or sick after the Match is begun, their Place may be supplied by any one chose conformably to the sixth Article, or in Case that can not be done, the other side shall be obliged to leave out one of their Gamesters, whomsoever They please. * 10th: that each match shall be for twelve Guineas of each Side; between the Duke & Mr. Brodrick. * 11th: that there shall be one Umpire of each side; & that if any of the Gamesters shall speak or give of their opinion, on any Point of the Game, they are to be turned out, & Voided in the Match; this not to extend to the Duke of Richmond & Mr. Brodrick. * 12th: If any Doubt or Dispute arises on any of the aforemd (''sic'') Articles, or whatever else is not settled therein, it shall be determined by the Duke of Richmond & Mr. Brodrick on their Honours; by whom the Umpires are likewise to be determined on any Difference between Them. * 13th: The Duke of Richmond's umpire shall pitch the Wickets when they play in Sussex; & Mr. Brodrick's when they play in Surry (''sic''); and each of Them shall be obliged to conform Himself strictly to the Agreements contained in the second Article. * 14th: The Batt (''sic'') Men for every one they count are to touch the Umpires Stick. * 15th: that it shall not be lawfull (''sic'') to fling down the Wicket: & that no Player shall be deemed out by any Wicket put down, unless with the Ball in Hand. * 16th: that both the Matches shall be played upon, and determined by, these Articles.
The Articles were signed "Richmond" and "A. Brodrick".<ref name=LTL/>
==Comparison with 1744 Laws of Cricket==
Comparison of the Articles to the [[Laws of Cricket|Laws of 1744]], which were widely adopted at that time, reveal that:<ref name=LTL>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#1727 |title=From Lads to Lord's – 1727 |publisher=John Leach |date=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629140522/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#1727 |archivedate=29 June 2011 }}</ref> * twelve a side, though this may include an umpire apiece, would have been difficult for Richmond if his matches against Gage were eleven a side and he fielded the same team in both matches. * the pitch length of 23 yards may be an error in the original document because the chain (22 yards) was definitely a used measure in 1727. * no run outs were allowed unless the fielder had the ball in his hand when breaking the wicket. * runs were only completed if the batsman touched the umpire's stick (which was probably a bat). * there is no mention of batsmen not being allowed to hit the ball twice.
In [[Harry Altham]]'s history, he discusses the possibility of a so-called "popping hole" being in use in the early 18th century but disclaims it as "a local and transitory variety of the regulation game". Altham pointed out, as evidence, that the fielder had to have the ball in his hand when breaking the wicket.<ref>Altham, p. 25.</ref>
[[Derek Birley]] in his social history comments upon the significance of Lady Day in the articles as "the usual hiring day for new servants", given that Richmond and Brodrick had servants in their teams.<ref>Birley, p. 19.</ref> One of Richmond's regular players was [[Thomas Waymark]] whom he ostensibly employed as a groom.<ref name=LTL/>
[[Rowland Bowen]] in his history comments on the 23-yard pitch length and says the 1744 Laws "expressly refer to twenty-two yards".<ref>Bowen, p. 43.</ref>
==Original document== In [[Timothy J. McCann]]'s ''Sussex Cricket'', the original handwritten articles document is pictured in one of the plates. It is sourced to the West Sussex Record Office (WSRO) re a [[Goodwood House]] manuscript which the WSRO acquired in 1884.<ref>McCann, plate 1 facing page lxiv.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=Altham |first=H. S. |authorlink=Harry Altham |title=A History of Cricket, Volume 1 (to 1914) |year=1962 |publisher=George Allen & Unwin |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Birley |first=Derek |authorlink=Derek Birley |title=A Social History of English Cricket |year=1999 |publisher=Aurum |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Bowen |first=Rowland |authorlink=Rowland Bowen |title=Cricket: A History of its Growth and Development |year=1970 |publisher=Eyre & Spottiswoode |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Major |first=John |authorlink=John Major |title=More Than A Game |year=2007 |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Marshall |first=John |authorlink= |title=The Duke who was Cricket |publisher=Muller |year=1961 |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Maun |first=Ian |title=From Commons to Lord's, Volume One: 1700 to 1750 |year=2009 |publisher=Roger Heavens |isbn=978-1-900592-52-9}} * {{cite book |last=McCann |first=Tim |authorlink=Timothy J. McCann |title=Sussex Cricket in the Eighteenth Century |year=2004 |publisher=Sussex Record Society |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Underdown |first=David |authorlink=David Underdown |title=Start of Play |year=2000 |publisher=Allen Lane |isbn=}}
==External links== * {{cite web|url=http://www.lords.org/laws-and-spirit/laws-of-cricket/laws/ |title=The official laws of cricket |publisher=Marylebone Cricket Club |date=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311210212/http://www.lords.org/laws-and-spirit/laws-of-cricket/laws/ |archivedate=11 March 2013 }}

[[File:Oddrun Hokland, Dianne Gerace, Irina Press, Ulla Flegel 1964.jpg|thumb|250px|Hurdles event at the first Olympic women's pentathlon in 1964]] [[File:Eero Lehtonen 1920.jpg|thumb|[[Eero Lehtonen]], Olympic pentathlon champion in 1920]] In the [[sport of athletics]], '''[[pentathlon]]s''' have taken various forms over the history of the sport, typically incorporating five [[track and field]] events. The only version of the event to remain at a high level of contemporary competition is the [[women's indoor pentathlon]], which is present on the programme for the [[IAAF World Indoor Championships]].
==Olympic athletics pentathlon== The athletics pentathlon featured on the [[Athletics at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games schedule]] in two separate periods. During the early history of the event, an [[Combined events at the Olympics|Olympic men's pentathlon]] was held and was present at the 1912, 1920 and 1924 games.<ref>[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ATH/mens-pentathlon.html Athletics Men's Pentathlon Medalists]. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref> The men's event was dropped, with the [[decathlon]] becoming the international standard. As women's events increasingly were contested internationally, the [[women's outdoor pentathlon]] was added and held for five straight editions from 1964 to 1980.<ref>[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/sports/ATH/womens-pentathlon.html Athletics Women's Pentathlon Medalists]. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref> The [[women's heptathlon]] superseded that event at international level in the early 1980s.
==Women's pentathlon== {{main|Women's pentathlon}} The [[International Women's Sports Federation]] was established in 1921 and the first reported women's pentathlon was in the [[1922 Women's Olympiad]] in [[Monte Carlo]].<ref name="Matthews2012">{{cite book|last=Matthews|first=Peter|title=Historical Dictionary of Track and Field|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQFHe9RwE0wC&pg=PA164|accessdate=11 May 2016|year=2012|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810867819|pages=164–5|chapter=Pentathlon}}</ref> The events were 60 m, 300 m, high jump, [[Two-handed throwing|two-hand]] javelin, and two-hand shot.<ref name="Matthews2012"/> In the late 1920s, the events were: shot and long jump on the first day, and 100 m, high jump, and javelin on the second day.<ref name="Matthews2012"/> The first world record recognised by the [[IAAF]] was set at the [[1934 Women's World Games]] by [[Gisela Mauermayer]].<ref name="Matthews2012"/> Prior to Olympic incorporation, the women's pentathlon featured at the [[AAA Championships]], [[USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships]] and the [[Soviet Athletics Championships]] from the 1950s onwards.<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/bc/bc3.htm British Athletics Championships 1945–1959]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref><ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/usaw.htm USA Women's Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref><ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/urs.htm Soviet Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref>
==Youth athletics== The outdoor pentathlon is in common usage at [[youth athletics|lower age categories of the sport]], allowing for easier training and event scheduling, and avoiding over-training of young athletes. For example, the lower division of the English Schools Combined Events Championships has pentathlons for both boys and girls.<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/bc/eso.htm English Schools Championships]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref> In [[high school athletics]] in North America, boys' and girls' pentathlons are held, consisting of the [[sprint hurdles]], long jump, shot put, high jump, and an [[800 metres|800 m run]] ([[1500 metres|1500 m run]] for men). The pentathlon is used because it is less stressful on the athletes than a full multi and because many high school meets only last one day, it allows the event to be contested in the time limit.<ref>[http://www.brianmac.co.uk/pent/index.htm Pentathlon]. Brian Mac. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref>
==Throws pentathlon== {{main|Throws pentathlon}} Less common, but standardised internationally is the [[throws pentathlon]]. This contains field [[throwing events]] only: [[hammer throw]], [[shot put]], [[discus throw]], [[javelin throw]], and [[weight throw]]. Although it does not have a position in high-profile global athletics competitions, it is present on the programme for the [[World Masters Athletics Championships]] for both men and women.<ref>[http://www.world-masters-athletics.org/records/outdoor-men WMA Championships Records Men] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903223836/http://www.world-masters-athletics.org/records/outdoor-men |date=2011-09-03 }}. World Masters Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref><ref>[http://www.world-masters-athletics.org/records/outdoor-women WMA Championships Records Women] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111105152/http://www.world-masters-athletics.org/records/outdoor-women |date=2012-01-11 }}. World Masters Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref> This event features at national level in many developed English-speaking nations.<ref>[http://www.nzmastersathletics.org.nz/throws_pentathlon/throws_pent.html NZMA Oceania Throws Pentathlon Challenge] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606214800/http://www.nzmastersathletics.org.nz/throws_pentathlon/throws_pent.html |date=June 6, 2014 }}. New Zealand Masters Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref><ref>[http://www.usatf.org/Events---Calendar/2013/USA-Masters-Throws-Championships/Results/Throws-Pentathlon-Awards-and-Stats.aspx Throws Pentathlon Awards and Stats]. [[USA Track & Field]]. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref><ref>[http://athleticsontario.ca/ontario-masters-throws-pentathlon-ultraweight-championships-decathlon-championships-and-relay-ruckus/ August 24-25: Ontario Masters Throws Pentathlon, Ultraweight Championships, Decathlon Championships and Relay Ruckus]. Athletics Ontario. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref><ref>[http://www.tomphillipsphotos.co.uk/bmafthrowspent15/ British Masters Throws Pentathlon 2015]. Tom Phillips. Retrieved on 2016-06-18.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Athletics events}} {{Portal bar|Athletics}}

{{refimprove|date=April 2017}} [[File:Bell tent detail.png|thumb|300px|Bell tents used by the British cavalry during the [[Crimean War]] in 1855. Photograph by [[Roger Fenton]].]] A '''bell [[tent]]''' is a human shelter for [[Dwelling|inhabiting]], traveling or leisure. The design is a simple structure, supported by a single central pole, covered with cotton [[canvas]]. The stability of the tent is reinforced with tension by [[Guy-wire|guy ropes]] connected around the top of the walls and being held down by pegs around the circumference to the ground. It has a circular floor plan of some 10 ft and larger.
The multiple sizes of bell tents can be suited to their use or preference and most have a spacious interior, with room to sleep a number of people. ==History== Indigenous people from around the world have used canvas as a natural breathable material, with suitable properties for use in the elements. Canvas is durable and versatile. Today's modern canvas can be [[waterproof]], [[Rot-proof|mildew resistant]], and [[flame retardant]]. A version of the bell tent, the [[sibley tent]] was invented by [[Henry Hopkins Sibley]], who had studied the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] [[tipi]] during the expeditions he carried out in the [[American Old West]]. He patented his tent design in 1858. The bell tent is characteristically differentiated from the sibley tent by its walls, raised larger entrance and guy ropes, without the extendable tripod or smoke hole, which were characteristics of the tipi. Bell tents have become the classic type of accommodation used in modern luxury camping, or [[glamping]], often kitted out with electricity hook-up, double beds, carpeting, refrigeration units and even coffee machines.[http://www.dorsetcountryholidaysandevents.co.uk/bell-tent-glamping.php Bell Tent glamping in Dorset] ==See also== *[[List of human habitation forms]] *[[Wigwam]] *[[Yurt]] *[[Glamping]] *[[Camping]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Tents}} [[Category:House types]] [[Category:Camping equipment]] [[Category:Tents]]

'''HC Salamat''' is a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[ice hockey]] team from [[Kirkkonummi]]. Salamat plays in the [[Mestis]] league. It was partly owned by [[Teemu Selänne]].
== History == Salamat was previously known as EPS (Espoon Palloseura) which stands for [[Espoo]]'s Ballclub. EPS played in the [[Suomi-Sarja]] which is the 3rd highest hockey league in Finland. In 2001 EPS was sold to Kirkkonummi and the club's name was changed to HC Salamat. In later that year the club celebrated promotion to [[Mestis]]
== Other == Salamat stands for [[lightning]]
==Notable players== * [[Hayley Wickenheiser]] (2003-04 season)
==External links== *[http://www.hcsalamat.com Official website, in Finnish]
[[Category:Mestis teams]] [[Category:Kirkkonummi]]

[[Maseru]], [[Lesotho]]| capacity = | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Lesotho Premier League]]| season = 2013–14| position = 7th| }} '''Lesotho Correctional Services''' football club are a team based in [[Maseru]], [[Lesotho]]. They compete in the [[Lesotho Premier League]] and have won four league titles. ==Achievements== *'''[[Lesotho Premier League]]: 6''' ::2000, 2002 ''(both as Lesotho Prisons Service)'' ::2007, 2008, 2011, 2012. ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[2008 CAF Champions League|2008]] – Preliminary Round ::[[2012 CAF Champions League|2012]] – Preliminary Round *'''[[CAF Confederation Cup]]: 0 appearance''' *'''[[CAF Super Cup]]: 0 appearance''' {{Lesotho Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Lesotho]] {{Lesotho-footyclub-stub}}

{{about|the former New York arena||Madison Square Garden (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Madison Square Garden I | nickname = | image = Madison Square Garden (c.1879).jpg | image_size = 350px | fullname = Madison Square Garden | location = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|44|34|N|73|59|08|W |display=inline,title |scale:1000_region:US-NY_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} | broke_ground = | built = 1874<ref name=ballp/> | opened = May 30, 1879 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1890 | demolished = 1890 | owner = [[William Kissam Vanderbilt]] | operator = [[William Kissam Vanderbilt]] | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 10,000 | }} '''Madison Square Garden''' (1879-1890) was an [[arena]] in [[New York City]] at the northeast corner of [[26th Street (Manhattan)|East 26th Street]] and [[Madison Avenue (Manhattan)|Madison Avenue]] in [[Manhattan]]. The first venue to use that name, it [[seating capacity|seated]] 10,000 spectators. It was replaced with a [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|new building]] on the same site.
==Origins== [[File:Barnums Hippodrome.jpg|thumb|right|287px|[[P. T. Barnum]]'s Roman Hippodrome, a predecessor to Madison Square Garden]] The site upon which Madison Square Garden was eventually established was originally occupied by a small passenger depot of the [[New York and Harlem Railroad]]. The site was vacated by the railroad in 1871 when it moved operations uptown to 42nd Street.<ref name=ballp>[http://hockey.ballparks.com/NHL/NewYorkRangers/1stoldindex.htm "Madison Square Garden I"] on Ballpark.com</ref> The site was vacant until 1874 when it was leased to [[P. T. Barnum]] who converted it into an open oval arena {{convert|270|ft|m}} long, with seats and benches in banks, which he named the ''Great Roman Hippodrome''<ref name=ballp /> where he presented circuses and other performances. The roofless building was also called ''Barnum's Monster Classical and Geological Hippodrome'' and measured {{convert|420|ft|m}} by {{convert|200|ft|m}}.<ref name=ballp />
In 1876 the open-air arena was leased to band leader [[Patrick Gilmore]], who renamed it ''Gilmore's Garden'' and presented flower shows, [[beauty contests]], music concerts, [[temperance (virtue)|temperance]] and [[revival meetings]], walking marathons,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gopnik|first1=Adam|authorlink=Adam Gopnik|title=Heaven’s Gaits|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/09/01/heavens-gaits|accessdate=29 August 2014|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|date=1 September 2014}}</ref> and the first [[Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show]], called at the time (1877) the "First Annual N.Y. Bench Show."<ref name=ballp /> Gilmore also presented [[boxing]], but since competitive boxing matches were technically illegal at the time, he called them "exhibitions" or "illustrated lectures."<ref name=ballp />
The next to lease the space was W. M. Tileston, who was an official of the dog show. He attempted to attract a more genteel crowd with [[tennis]], a riding school and an ice carnival;<ref name=ballp /> the arena had one of the first indoor ice rinks in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.howstuffworks.com/ice-rink1.html|title=How Ice Rinks Work|author=Russell-Ausley, Melissa}}</ref>
==Naming== After the death of [[Commodore Vanderbilt]], who owned the site, his grandson [[William Kissam Vanderbilt]] took back control and announced on May 31, 1879 that the arena was to be renamed "Madison Square Garden."<ref name=ballp /> Vanderbilt presented sporting events such as indoor [[track and field]] meets, a convention of [[Elks]], the [[Horse show|National Horse Show]] and more boxing, including some bouts featuring [[John L. Sullivan]], who began a four-year series of exhibitions in July 1882, drawing over-capacity crowds.<ref name=ballp /> P.T. Barnum also used the Garden to exhibit [[Jumbo]], the elephant he had bought from the [[London Zoo]]; he drew sufficient business to recover the $10,000 pricetag.<ref name=ballp />
Another notable use of the first Garden was as a [[velodrome]], an oval bicycle racing track with banked curves. At the time, bicycle racing was one of the biggest sports in the country. "[T]he top riders [were] among the sports stars of their day. The bike races at Madison Square Garden were all the rage around the turn of the 20th century."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/29/nyregion/thecity/29gear.html| title =Unstoppable |last=Weyland|first=Jocko|date=2007-04-29|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> Madison Square Garden was the most important bicycle racing track in the United States and the Olympic discipline known as the [[Madison (cycling)|Madison]] is named after the original Garden.
However, the roofless Garden was hot in the summertime and freezing in the wintertime. Vanderbilt eventually sold what ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' called his "patched-up, grimy, drafty, combustible old shell" to a syndicate that included [[J. P. Morgan]], [[Andrew Carnegie]], [[James Stillman]] and [[W. W. Astor]], who closed it to build a new arena designed by noted architect [[Stanford White]]. Demolition began in July 1889,<ref name=ballp /> and the [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|second Madison Square Garden]], which cost more than a half-million dollars to build, opened on June 6, 1890. It was demolished in 1926, and the [[New York Life Building]], designed by [[Cass Gilbert]] and completed in 1928, replaced it on the site.
==See also== * [[Madison Square]] * [[Madison Square Garden (1890)]] * [[Madison Square Garden (1925)]] * [[Madison Square Garden|Madison Square Garden (1968)]] * [[Madison Square Garden Bowl]]

{{Other uses|Khodynka (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = | fullname = Megasport Sport Palace | nickname = Megasport Arena | former_names = Khodynka Arena (2006–2007) | image = Ice palace in Moscow.JPG | caption = The exterior of Megasport Sport Palace. | location = Khodynka avenue 3 [[Moscow]] 125252 , [[Russia]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|47|12|N|37|32|25|E|region:RU_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = November 2, 2005 | opened = December 15, 2006 | publictransit = {{MOSMETRO-bull|7|}} [[Polezhayevskaya]]

[[Euro|EUR €]]35 million | architect = Andrei Bokov | tenants = [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] (2016–present) | seating_capacity = [[Ice Hockey]] (12,126){{cite web|url=http://www.hockey-palace.ru/node/35|title=Варианты трансформации арены|language=Russian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018211825/http://www.hockey-palace.ru/node/35|archivedate=2016-10-18|df=}}
[[Gymnastics]] (12,926)
[[Tennis]] (13,126)
[[Basketball]] (13,344)
[[Boxing]] (13,926) | dimensions = }} '''Megasport Sport Palace'''{{cite web|url=http://www.hockey-palace.ru/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022035746/http://www.hockey-palace.ru/ |archivedate=2016-10-22 |df= }} ({{lang-ru|Дворец спорта "Мегаспорт"}} '''Translite''' ''Dvorets sporta Megasport'', formerly, '''Khodynka Arena''' or '''Ice Sport Palace on the Khodynka Field'''), is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] that is located in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. The arena is situated in the [[Khodynka Field]]. The arena has a maximum [[seating capacity]] of 13,926 people.Eurosport, [http://www.eurosport.ru/icehockey/world-championships/2007/sport_sto1138695.shtml "article"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926234752/http://www.eurosport.ru/icehockey/world-championships/2007/sport_sto1138695.shtml |date=September 26, 2007 }}, ''[[Eurosport]] , April 5, 2007. The arena is primarily used to host [[basketball]] and [[ice hockey]] games. ==History== [[File:Матч ЦСКА – Реал Мадрид в ДС «Мегаспорт» 1 февраля 2018 года · 2.jpg|thumb|left|Interior of the arena during a basketball match in February 2018]] Megasport Sport Palace was completed in December 2006.Sport-Express, [http://www.sport-express.ru/art.shtml?131989 "article"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070127212807/http://www.sport-express.ru/art.shtml?131989 |date=January 27, 2007}}, ''[[Sport-Express]], December 15, 2006.Sport-Express, [http://www.sport-express.ru/art.shtml?131300 "article"]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}}, ''[[Sport-Express]] , December 1, 2006. It was one of the arenas that hosted the [[2007 Men's World Ice Hockey Championships]]. It was also the host venue of the [[Sultan Ibragimov]] versus [[Evander Holyfield]] World Heavyweight Title Fight, on October 13, 2007. On 23 January 2008, [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] hosted a [[EuroLeague]] [[Euroleague 2007-08 Regular Season Group A|regular season]] game against [[Saski Baskonia|TAU Cerámica]] in the arena, in front of a near sellout 13,000 attendance crowd.[http://www.euroleague.net Euroleague.net] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229045851/http://www.euroleague.net/ |date=December 29, 2016 }}, [http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame/report?gamecode=146 GAME REPORT CSKA Moscow 70 -62 Tau Ceramica] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818080013/http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame/report?gamecode=146 |date=August 18, 2016 }}, January 23, 2008 In November 2008, the [[2008 Cup of Russia|Cup of Russia]] [[figure skating competition]] was held at the arena.{{cite web|url= http://news.mossport.ru/news_browse.asp?NewsID=54747&CatID=&SportID=28631&DistrictID= | title=Cup of Russia figure skating Grand Prix | language=Russian | accessdate=2008-11-23}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Another important event hosted at the arena was the [[Men's CEV Champions League 2006–07|2006–07]] [[CEV Champions League]] Final four,[http://www.vcdynamo.ru/club/vizitka/ Визитка] {{ru icon}} in which [[Tours VB]] won the title, after defeating [[VfB Friedrichshafen]].[http://www.cev.lu/mmp-cgi/show.pl?cmd=tmpl&id=851&id2=22&id3=216&id4=3&id5=3&state=p_prj_game_summary&key=0 2006/2007 European Cups - RESULTS INDESIT EUROPEAN CHAMPIONS LEAGUE MEN - 2006/2007 - Final Four in MOSCOW (RUS) on 31/03 & 01/04/2007 Final Match 1/2 - Match F-004]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Megasport Arena was rumored to be the venue for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009|54th Eurovision Song Contest]] in 2009, but instead the competition was held at the [[Olympic Stadium (Moscow arena)|Olympic Indoor Arena]], in Moscow. On March 24, 2011, the International Skating Union (ISU) relocated the [[2011 World Figure Skating Championships]] to the Megasport Arena, in Moscow.{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/winter_sports/9435021.stm | title = Moscow to host of Figure Skating World Championships | last = | first = |date = March 24, 2011 | work = [[BBC News]] | accessdate = March 24, 2011}} This decision followed the cancellation of the championships in Tokyo, Japan, due to the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. The championships were staged from April 24 to May 1, 2011. The [[2011 European Curling Championships]] were also hosted at the arena, in December 2011. In 2016, the arena became the home arena of the [[VTB United League]] club [[PBC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], for [[EuroLeague]] games. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Megasport Arena}} *{{official website|http://www.hockey-palace.ru/}} {{ru icon}} *[http://www.hockeyarenas.net/index.php3?page=3000&ctID=ru&arID=1319 Khodynka Arena at Hockeyarenas.net] *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/europe/russia/moscow_khodynka.shtml Khodynka Arena at worldstadiums.com] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box |title=[[CEV Champions League]]

page.title: Mental health in the Australian Football League

revision.comment: /* top */en-AUS, dmy dates; clean up using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2018}} [[Mental health]] refers to a person's mental state, well-being,<ref>{{Cite web|title = the definition of mental health|url = http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/mental+health|website = Dictionary.com|accessdate = 2015-08-31}}</ref> and ability to cope with the daily stresses of life.<ref>{{Cite web|title = CDC - Mental Health Basics - Mental Health|url = https://www.cdc.gov/mentalhealth/basics.htm|website = www.cdc.gov|accessdate = 2015-08-31}}</ref> Good mental health also means that one has the ability to be mentally resilient, have a good life balance, having an absence of [[mental disorder]]s and the ability to enjoy life.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Life skills and mental health - ProQuest|url = http://search.proquest.com/openview/7b94b087f3c54c7872f86ff0cd41d98f/1?pq-origsite=gscholar|website = search.proquest.com|accessdate = 2015-09-02}}</ref> Elite athletes such as those competing in the [[Australian Football League]](AFL), are at higher risk of developing a mental health disorders such as depression, anxiety, social anxiety, panic attacks and eating disorders.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = BMC Psychiatry {{!}} Full text {{!}} Barriers and facilitators to mental health help-seeking for young elite athletes: a qualitative study|url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-244X/12/157|website = www.biomedcentral.com|accessdate = 2015-08-31}}</ref> 16–34 years olds are also in the high risk category, which is the average age of a football player and extends to those who are being [[Australian Football League draft|drafted]],<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|title = Manage Your Mind Wellbeing Program|url = http://www.aflplayers.com.au/article/inside-football-feature-manage-your-mind-wellbeing-program/|accessdate = 2015-09-02}}</ref> this puts AFL players in both high risk categories.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = http://ac.els-cdn.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/S1440244014000759/1-s2.0-S1440244014000759-main.pdf?_tid=e074c530-5122-11e5-89ad-00000aacb35e&acdnat=1441164774_11d2198e0d4052867715256b5f24b9b8|title = The mental health of Australian elite athletes|author1=Gulliver. A |author2=Griffiths. K. M. |author3=Mackinnon. P. J. |author4=Stanimirovic. R. |date = 2014|journal = Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport|volume = 18|issue = 3|pages = 255|doi = 10.1016/j.jsams.2014.04.006|pmid = 24882147|access-date = }}</ref> A study conducted by [[Helen Christensen]] and Alison Parsons showed that 1 in 5 elite athletes suffered depressive symptoms.<ref name=":1" /> Playing elite sports is a great challenge emotionally, mentally as well as physically,<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|url = |title = External and internal factors influencing happiness in elite collegiate athletes|last = Denny|first = Katherine G|date = 2009|journal = Child Psychiatry and Human Development|doi = |pmid = }}</ref> some players can cope with all of these pressures while others cannot handle it and therefore suffer from a lack of mental health.
== Society and culture ==
AFL players are often forced to conform to the norms but also have high expectations placed on them such as extraordinary behavior, appearance and performance.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1469029215000758|title=A subculture of mental toughness in an Australian Football League club|first1=Tristan J.|last1=Coulter|first2=Clifford J.|last2=Mallett|first3=Jefferson A.|last3=Singer|date=1 January 2016|publisher=|journal=Psychology of Sport and Exercise|volume=22|pages=98–113|doi=10.1016/j.psychsport.2015.06.007}}</ref> They are perceived to be tough, and mentally tough, if they conform to these norms and display qualities such as having self-belief, mental and emotional resilience and a tough attitude.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Towards an Understanding of Mental Toughness in Australian Football|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/10413200801998556|journal = Journal of Applied Sport Psychology|date = 2008-07-18|issn = 1041-3200|pages = 261–281|volume = 20|issue = 3|doi = 10.1080/10413200801998556|first = Daniel F.|last = Gucciardi|first2 = Sandy|last2 = Gordon|first3 = James A.|last3 = Dimmock}}</ref> They are also expected to be extremely masculine and not show signs of emotional stress and upset, if they show these signs they are then perceived as weak and tend to be dropped from the team or squad.<ref name=":2" /> Usually only 35% of elite athletes will seek help from a professional as they tend to believe they are alright and can get better by themselves. They tend to be worried about others finding out about these issues as there seems to be a [[social stigma]] that they are weak if they suffer from any of these problems.<ref name=":0" /> The masculine stereotypes associated with AFL players is a potential barrier for players to come out and talk about their mental health problems.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|title = Proactive approach to mental health|url = http://www.aflplayers.com.au/article/proactive-approach-to-mental-health/|accessdate = 2015-09-02}}</ref>
When a player exaggerates their negative performances or situations it often leads to mental health problems.<ref name=":1" /> Media has a big role in all of this. Players are constantly scrutinized about performance, the way they act, the way they look, etc., and the players then see this and tend to dwell on all of the negatives. This messes with the players psychologically and places an added pressure on them to perform and act better. [[File:Barry hall.jpg|thumb|Barry Hall]]
== History == There have been a few cases made public of AFL players suffering from mental health problems. In 2015 it was noted that [[Mitch Clarke]] from [[Geelong Football Club]] has been suffering from mental health problems.<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/mitch-clark-dealing-with-ongoing-mental-health-issues-chris-scott-20150508-ggxr89.html|title = The Age|last = Pierk & Niall|date = 2015|work = |access-date = |via = }}</ref> When questioned it was not spoken about very much and all quite hidden. He was withdrawn from the team even after a huge win which sparked conversation in the community but Mitch Clarke never spoke much about it.
Also in 2015 [[Adam Goodes]] took a week off training and playing because of the 'emotional toll'<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://www.smh.com.au/afl/sydney-swans/sydney-swans-veteran-adam-goodes-will-not-play-this-weekend-against-adelaide-20150729-gin6du.html|title = Sydney Morning Herald|last = Wu|first = Andrew|date = 2015|work = |access-date = |via = }}</ref> he was put under during the season, receiving boos and racist comments from the crowd. He was also under analyses by the media which was all too much for him so it led to him taking time off and away from the sport.
[[Barry Hall]] was also seen to be suffering mental health problems, admitting he had been suffering depression throughout his AFL career and that he "had nothing to get out of bed for" (Hall, 2011). [[Simon Hogan]] was another player who came out about their depression and had contemplated killing himself during his career. [[Lance Picioane]] who played for Adelaide, Hawthorn and the Kangaroos said how he struggled to understand that he was actually suffering from depression and that it wasn't him just feeling a little bit down.<ref name=":6" />
[[Wayne Schwass]], [[Nathan Thompson (Australian footballer)|Nathan Thompson]] and [[Heath Black]] are other players who have come out and spoken about their struggle with anxiety and depression throughout their football careers.
== Causes == There are many factors that lead to bad mental health in AFL players.
=== Pressures and expectations ===
Pressure to win and to perform well week in and week out contributes to the bad mental state of some AFL players. Having such a heavy burden on their shoulders impacts their state of mind, and when they do under perform this can negatively affect a players mental health.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> There are also pressures from society to act professionally and look the part,<ref name=":0" /> be fit, strong and well groomed. They have high expectations on them as players and are encouraged to be the ideal male who is masculine, athletic, strong etc.. and this pressure is coming from within the club as well.<ref name=":2" /> If a player has a bad game it is written all over the media and it is hard for it not to affect the player emotionally.
=== Injuries ===
[[Injury]] and the risk of injury also contributes to this lack of mental health because if a player does become injured they will have a lower or no income and their position in next season is on the rocks so knowing this makes them stress. Being injured also means they cannot exercise as much and this sudden drop in physical activity levels makes the player more likely to become anxious or depressed as physical activity is a mood enhancer.<ref>Eriksson, S., & Gard, G. (2011). Physical exercise and depression. ''Physical Therapy Reviews'', ''16''(4), 261-268. doi:10.1179/1743288X11Y.0000000026</ref> On average a total of 40 players miss a total of 142 games a season.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Epidemiology of injuries in the Australian Football League, seasons 1997–2000|journal = British Journal of Sports Medicine|date = 2002-02-01|issn = 0306-3674|pmc = 1724448|pmid = 11867491|pages = 39–44|volume = 36|issue = 1|doi = 10.1136/bjsm.36.1.39|first = J|last = Orchard|first2 = H|last2 = Seward}}</ref> This is a huge number and a constant lingering concern for players. The whole process of finding out about their injury to [[Physical therapy|rehabilitation]] and returning to the sport is an emotional roller-coaster for players as they have strong negative feelings when they find out about their diagnosis, to struggling through rehab then having the pressure to perform.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Psychological Impact of Long-Term Injury on Australian Football League Players|url = http://www.tandfonline.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/doi/full/10.1080/10413200.2014.897269#abstract|doi = 10.1080/10413200.2014.897269| journal=Journal of Applied Sport Psychology|volume=26|issue=4|pages = 377|year=2014|last1 = Ruddock-Hudson|first1 = Mandy|last2 = o'Halloran|first2 = Paul|last3 = Murphy|first3 = Greg}}</ref>
[[Head injuries in the Australian Football League|Head injuries]] may affect the mind more directly.
[[File:Afl ruckwork.jpg|thumb|Australian football [[Ruckman (Australian rules football)|ruck contests]], a common cause of injury]]
=== Other ===
The pressure of location and relocation is another toll on players. When [[Australian Football League draft|drafting]] comes around young players are unsure what team will draft them.Having to relocate their entire lives to go train and play with a team is such a stress on the young players and can cause anxiety.<ref name=":5" /> Starting in a new team with new people, a new training structure and lifestyle can be a big shock to some players and they may experience social anxiety and exclusion which could lead to negative thoughts.
During the week each player is critiqued by coaching staff to see where they can improve in their game, but constantly being under the pump can be mentally exhausting for players.<ref name=":5" />
The environment in which they live and train in impacts a players mental health as it can affect the mental resilience which they build and creates their personality which could affect if they fit in or not.<ref name=":4" /> It also affects their natural resiliency to tough situations and how they handle things that come their way. If they do not have support from either family or friends everything can fall apart.
== Prevention and treatment == Prevention, intervention and treatment for mental health has been neglected for quite some time and has never been a high priority to create groups to support this.<ref name=":3"><nowiki>World, H. O. (2010). Mental Health Development : Targeting People with Mental Health Conditions as a Vulnerable Group. Albany, NY, USA: World Health Organization (WHO). Retrieved from http://www.ebrary.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au</nowiki></ref> 844 000 people commit suicide every year<ref name=":3" /> in the world so it is vital something is done to help the AFL players. It is shown that organised programs are one of the most effective ways to help treat mental illnesses such as depression and having a full-time staff member to facilitate this would be a greater benefit.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Should Mental Health Interventions Be Locally Grown or Factory-Farmed?|url = http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org.ipacez.nd.edu.au/doi/abs/10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.13010043|journal = American Journal of Psychiatry|date = 2013-01-01|pmc = 4249622|pmid = 23545790|volume = 170|issue = 4|pages = 362–5|doi = 10.1176/appi.ajp.2013.13010043|first = Gregory E.|last = Simon|first2 = Evette J.|last2 = Ludman}}</ref>
=== AFL mental health framework ===
AFL has put a framework in place to ensure the best mental health of the players and it encourages early identification and intervention. They hope to remove any stigmas from society and the people involved in AFL about mental health disorders. They aim to educate their players on mental health issues with online, face to face and peer to peer programs. They are hoping to create a space where the industry is able to recognize symptoms and to aid in early intervention.
=== "Manage Your Mind" well-being program ===
This is a program set up by the [[AFL Players Association]], teaching players about the signs and symptoms of mental illness so they can better understand the difference between feeling a bit sad one day and depression. Through a three session course players are exposed to realizing their own values, different mental health stories and how these both relate back to their lives and then being able to change anything they aren't happy with. They are also taught about different emotions and ways to surface them and talk about them to other people.<ref name=":5" />
=== AFL Players Association programs ===
The AFL Players Association also have two other programs similar to the Manage Your Mind Well-being Program. Practical Mindfulness is another which is a hands on course that helps the players to be able to manage stress and build resilience to all the negative influences.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Mind Mechanics|url = http://www.aflplayers.com.au/article/wellbeing-programs/|accessdate = 2015-09-02}}</ref> Team wise is the third program they offer which is targeted at coaching staff, captains and influential players to develop skills in aiding other players to speak up and to be positive role models.<ref name=":6" />
== See also == * [[Sport psychology]] * [[Mental health in association football]] * [[Depression in the Australian Football League]]
== References == {{Reflist|3}}
== External links == * [http://headspace.org.au/ Headspace] * [https://www.beyondblue.org.au/ Beyond Blue] * [http://yourstruly.org.au/#/story Yours truly] * [http://s.afl.com.au/staticfile/AFL%20Tenant/AFL/Files/Respect%20and%20Responsibility/AFL_MentalHealthPolicy.pdf AFL mental health policy] * [http://www.aflplayers.com.au/article/inside-football-feature-manage-your-mind-wellbeing-program/ Manage Your Mind Wellbeing Program]

{{Infobox UK Racecourse | Name = Newcastle | Image = [[Image:Newcastle rc.jpg|250px]] | Caption = View of the stands at Newcastle Racecourse. | Website = http://www.newcastle-racecourse.co.uk | Location = [[Gosforth Park]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] | Owner = [[Arena Racing Company]] | Opened = 1882 | Channel = [[At The Races]] | CourseType = Left-handed, [[Flat racing|Flat]]
[[National Hunt]] | NotableRaces = | Prev = [[Newbury Racecourse|Newbury]] | Next = [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]] }} '''Newcastle Racecourse''' is a [[horse racing]] course located at [[Gosforth Park]] near [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[England]], owned by [[Arena Racing Company]]. It stages both [[Flat racing|flat]] and [[National Hunt racing]], with its biggest meeting being the [[Northumberland Plate]] held annually in June. ==History== Horseracing began in the North East over 350 years ago, beginning in [[Killingworth]] in the early 17th century. A King's Plate for 5 year olds, run in 3 mile heats was instigated by [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] in 1753.{{cite book |last=Whyte |first=James Christie |authorlink= |title=History of the British turf, from the earliest period to the present day, Volume I | url=http://openlibrary.org/books/OL6544990M/History_of_the_British_turf |accessdate=1 May 2013 |year=1840 |publisher=H. Colburn |location=[[London]]|page=402}} The [[Town Moor, Newcastle upon Tyne|Town Moor]] hosted the first recorded Northumberland Plate in 1833 and did so until 1881 when the race transferred to [[Gosforth Park|High Gosforth Park]]. 1882 saw the first running of the Plate at Gosforth Park with a new flat and chase course, new stand and stabling for 100 horses. In April, 2002 the [[Scotland|Scottish]] businessman [[David Williamson (businessman)|David Williamson]] joined Newcastle Racecourse as managing director and during a six-year period he transformed their fortunes and helped boost turnover from £2.5m to £6.5m. The Northumberland Plate weekend now brings in £30m to the regional economy and he also introduced Ladies' Day which now attracts over 15,000 racegoers. In April, 2008 he was headhunted by [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and appointed Executive Director (Operations). {{cite web |url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/north-east-news/todays-news/2008/04/05/toon-win-for-the-racetrack-wizard-61634-20723806/ |title=Toon win for the racetrack wizard |publisher=journallive.co.uk |accessdate=2008-07-30 }} Williamson was replaced by [[Mark Spincer]]. In December 2013 Newcastle's owners, [[Arena Racing Company]], announced plans to change the flat turf course into an all-weather track while retaining a turf jump racing course.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/horse-racing/25266074 |title=Newcastle Racecourse plans all-weather floodlit track |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 December 2013}} The new tapeta track was completed in early 2016 with the first meeting held on 17 May of that year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newcastle-racecourse.co.uk/about-us/news-details.php?newsid=270|title=News {{!}} Newcastle Racecourse Racing & Events|website=www.newcastle-racecourse.co.uk|access-date=2016-06-01}} ==Notable races== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! style="width:70px" |Month ! style="width:80px" |DOW ! Race Name ! style="width:60px" |Type ! style="width:70px" | '''Grade''' ! style="width:80px" |Distance ! style="width:50px" |Age/Sex |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|1|February}} | style="text-align:center" |Saturday | [[Eider Chase]] | style="text-align:center" |Chase | style="text-align:center" | Handicap | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|6639|4m 1f }} | style="text-align:center" |5yo + |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|2|March}} | style="text-align:center" |Saturday | [[Burradon Stakes]] | style="text-align:center" |Flat | style="text-align:center" | Listed | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|1614|1m 5y }} | style="text-align:center" |3yo |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|3|June}} | style="text-align:center" |Saturday | [[Chipchase Stakes]] | style="text-align:center" |Flat | style="text-align:center" | Group 3 | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|1207|6f }} | style="text-align:center" |3yo + |- | style="text-align:center" |{{Sort|4|June}} | style="text-align:center" |Saturday | [[Northumberland Plate]] | style="text-align:center" |Flat | style="text-align:center" | Handicap | {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Peel Park | fullname = Peel Park | location = [[Accrington]], Lancashire, England | opened = 1919 | closed = 1966 | owner = | tenants = [[Accrington Stanley F.C. (1891)|Accrington Stanley F.C.]] (1919–1963) | seating_capacity = 9,000 (at closing)
17,634 (record attendance) }} '''Peel Park''' was a [[association football|football]] stadium in [[Accrington]], Lancashire that was the home of [[Accrington Stanley F.C. (1891)|Accrington Stanley F.C.]] between 1919 until their dissolution in 1966. The record attendance was set in a friendly match against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 15 November 1954 with 17,634 spectators in attendance. The record for a league match occurred against [[York City F.C.|York City]] on 11 April 1955 with 15,425 spectators. ==References== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/1962374.stm Article on stadium] *[http://www.wsc.co.uk/content/view/2921/29/ Stadium information] {{Accrington Stanley F.C.}} {{Borough of Hyndburn culture}} [[Category:Accrington Stanley F.C.]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Accrington]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Hyndburn]] [[Category:Sport in Hyndburn]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1919]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] {{Lancashire-struct-stub}} {{England-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Professional Cricketers' Association''' is the representative body of past and present [[first-class cricket]]ers in England and Wales, founded in 1967 by former England fast bowler [[Fred Rumsey]] (when it was known as the Cricketers' Association). In the 1970s, the PCA arranged a standard employment contract and minimum wage for professional cricketers in first-class cricket in England and Wales. ==History== Former Somerset and England fast bowler Fred Rumsey founded the Professional Cricketers’ Association in 1967. Before the creation of the PCA English cricket players had little to no say in the administration of the game in England and Wales. Rumsey's creation of a players union was recognised when the PCA recently appointed him honorary life founder member and a vice-president. [[John Arlott]] became the first president in 1968. ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack|Wisden]]'' noted that his
"democratic views and wise counsel earned him much respect in the cricket world and among the players. His moderation and tact helped in some tight corners, notably at the time of the [[World Series Cricket|Packer Affair]], when he strove to keep the Cricketers' Association neutral."{{cite web|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/player/8522.html|title=Profile: John Arlott|work=Wisden Cricketer's Almanack obituary|publisher=CricInfo|accessdate=29 July 2009}}
[[Mike Edwards (cricketer)|Mike Edwards]] was appointed the first treasurer in 1968, and was elected chairman in 1970. He subsequently resigned the post following a majority decision by the membership to accept a donation from the [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]] in [[apartheid]]-era South Africa. Harold Goldblatt is a chartered accountant who was asked by Arlott to assist the PCA. It was he who negotiated the minimum wage, the standard contract and insurance cover for all players.{{cn|date=June 2013}} He utilized the over-rate fines to form the Cricket Association Charity, for the benefit of former County players who had fallen on hard financial times, and the charity has helped over 80 such players to date. He was appointed senior vice president for life in appreciation of the 30 years of service he gave to the association.{{cn|date=January 2014}} In an article about the PCA originally published in the March 1979 issue of ''[[The Cricketer]]'', Arlott wrote that Goldblatt was "invaluable as financial adviser".''[[John Arlott|Arlott]] on Cricket'', edited by [[David Rayvern Allen]], Fontana/Collins, 1985 edition, {{ISBN|0-00-637007-1}}, pp217-220. The PCA holds an annual awards dinner, with the Reg Hayter Cup for the [[PCA Player of the Year]] award being one of the more prestigious awards in the domestic game. == See also == * [[Australian Cricketers' Association]] * [[Federation of International Cricketers' Associations]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.thepca.co.uk/ Official website] * [http://www.thepca.co.uk/8127.html Film on the history of the Professional Cricketers' Association] {{Cricket in England}} [[Category:Sports trade unions]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1967]] [[Category:Trade unions in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Cricketers' associations]] [[Category:1967 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Cricket administration in England]] [[Category:Cricket administration in Wales]] {{cricket-administration-stub}} {{UK-trade-union-stub}}

page.title: Southern League Most Outstanding Pitcher Award

revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Southern League
Most Outstanding Pitcher Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = Southern League's Regular Season Most Outstanding Pitcher | presenter = | host = | location = | country = United States | reward = | year = 1972 | year2 = | holder = [[Zack Brown]] | website = }} The '''Southern League Most Outstanding Pitcher Award''' ('''MOP''') is an annual award given to the best [[pitcher]] in [[minor league baseball]]'s [[Southern League (baseball)|Southern League]]. In 1972, [[Bill Campbell (baseball)|Bill Campbell]] won the first ever Southern League MOP Award. In 1992, [[Jim Converse]] and [[Jerry Spradlin]] were named Co-MOPs. For five years in a row from 1978 to 1982, pitchers from the [[Nashville Sounds]] won the Southern League MOP Award. Eight players from the [[Jacksonville Suns]]/[[Jacksonville Expos|Expos]] have been selected for the MOP Award, more than any other teams in the league, followed by the [[Birmingham Barons]] and [[Nashville Sounds]] (5); the [[Columbus Astros]]/[[Carolina Mudcats (1991–2011)|Carolina Mudcats]], [[Greenville Braves|Greenville]]/[[Mississippi Braves]], and [[Orlando Twins]]/[[Montgomery Biscuits]] (4); the [[Charlotte O's]]/[[Charlotte Knights|Knights]], [[Huntsville Stars]]/[[Biloxi Shuckers]], [[Knoxville Blue Jays]]/[[Tennessee Smokies]], [[Nashville Xpress]]/[[Mobile BayBears]], and [[West Tenn Diamond Jaxx]]/[[Jackson Generals]] (3); the [[Chattanooga Lookouts]] (2); and the [[Charlotte Hornets (baseball)|Charlotte Hornets]] (1). Five players each from the [[Cincinnati Reds]] and [[Minnesota Twins]] [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) organizations have won the MOP Award, more than any others, followed by the [[Atlanta Braves]] and [[Chicago White Sox]] organizations (4); the [[Houston Astros]], [[Milwaukee Brewers]], [[New York Yankees]], [[Seattle Mariners]], and [[Toronto Blue Jays]] organizations (3); the [[Baltimore Orioles]], [[Chicago Cubs]], [[Detroit Tigers]], [[Florida Marlins|Florida]]/[[Miami Marlins]], [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], and [[Montreal Expos]] organizations (2); and the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], [[San Diego Padres]], and [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] organizations (1). ==Key== {| class="wikitable" |- |style="background-color:#BBFFBB;"|{{center|*}}||Indicates multiple award winners in the same year |} ==Winners== [[File:Mark Buehrle (6034761280).jpg|thumb|right|[[Mark Buehrle]], 2000 Southern League MOP]] [[File:Ricky Nolasco Marlins.JPG|thumb|right|[[Ricky Nolasco]], 2005 Southern League MOP]] Hornets]] |[[Minnesota Twins]] |13–10 |0 |2.42 |204 |{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=campbe005wil|title=Bill Campbell Minor League Statistics and History|work=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=March 3, 2015}} |- |1973 !scope="row" style="text-align:center"|{{sort name|Doug|Konieczny}} |[[Columbus Astros]] |[[Houston Astros]] |12–12 |0 |2.66 {{Refimprove|date=March 2016}} {{infobox football tournament |organiser = [[Sussex County Football Association]] | current = [[2016-17 Sussex Senior Cup]] | logo = | founded = {{Start date and age|1882|df=yes}} | number of teams = 50 (2016-17) | region = [[Sussex]] | current champions = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]]
(14th title) | most successful club = [[Worthing F.C.|Worthing]]
(21 titles) | website = }} The '''Sussex Senior Cup''' is an annual [[association football]] knock-out cup competition for men's football clubs in the English county of [[Sussex]] and is the county senior cup of the [[Sussex County Football Association|Sussex FA]]. Its official name is the '''Sussex Senior Challenge Cup'''. For sponsorship purposes, from 2012 to 2018 it is also known as the '''Parafix Sussex Senior Cup''' after a new three-year sponsorship deal was agreed in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.sussexexpress.co.uk/sport/local-football/parafix-agree-new-deal-to-sponsor-sussex-senior-cup-1-6914679|title=Parafix Agree New Deal to Sponsor Sussex Senior Cup|publisher=Sussex Express|date=20 August 2015|accessdate=22 May 2016}} First played in the 1882-83 season, shortly after the founding of the [[Sussex County Football Association]] in 1882, the first winners of the cup were Brighton Rangers. Other teams who won the cup in its early history are [[Burgess Hill Town F.C.|Burgess Hill]], [[Lancing College]] and [[Eastbourne Town F.C.|Eastbourne]]. The team with most title wins in the competition's history are [[Worthing F.C.|Worthing]] but teams who have been successful in the cup recently are Sussex's two [[Football League]] teams, [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] and [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]]. [[Bognor Regis Town]] won the competition a record five times in succession between 1980 and 1984. Winners also qualify for a place in the Sussex FA Community Shield match, traditionally the opening match each season in Sussex football. [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] are the current holders of the Sussex Senior Cup, having beaten [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] 2–1 in the 2018 final in a repeat of the 2017 final. ==History== Shortly after the [[Sussex County Football Association]] was founded in 1882 the inaugural competition of the Sussex Senior Club took place for the 1882-83 season. Brighton Rangers won the final of the first competition 3-0. Founder members of Sussex County FA include the [[Public school (United Kingdom)|public schools]] of [[Lancing College]], [[Brighton College]] and [[Ardingly College]] and their old-boy teams dominated the cup early on, along with clubs such as [[Burgess Hill Town F.C.|Burgess Hill]] and [[Eastbourne Town F.C.|Eastbourne]], whose teams were made up of upper and middle class players.{{cite book|first1=Tim|last1=Carder|first2=Roger|last2=Harris|title=Seagulls! The Story of Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|year=1993|publisher=Goldstone Books|isbn=0952133709}} The cup was initially contested only by amateur clubs. At the time Sussex's only professional club, [[Brighton and Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton and Hove Albion]] tried to enter the competition in 1905 but had to withdraw because of clashing dates. Albion won the Sussex Wartime Cup in 1943 but only entered the normal competition in 1946. Albion entered the competition again in 1975-76 following the abolition of the distinction between amateur and professional clubs in the English game. Following the 1913–14 competition, the cup was suspended due to the [[First World War]], and resumed in 1919–20. During the Second World War the winners of the Sussex Wartime Cup were awarded the Sussex Senior Cup. The Sussex Wartime Cup took place on a league basis and a competition was held in every year during the Second World War except for 1940-41 when no competition for the Sussex Senior Cup was held. Under Jack Pearce, [[Bognor Regis Town F.C.|Bognor Regis Town]] dominated the Sussex Senior Cup in the 1980s, winning the cup six times, including a record five times in succession, and finishing runners-up once. From 1950–51 the cup final took place at the [[Goldstone Ground]] every year until 1995 when Brighton sold their ground to developers. A crowd of over 7,000, the cup's highest attendance in recent years, saw the 2010–11 season final take place at Brighton's new [[American Express Community Stadium]] on 16 July 2011. It was the first competitive match to be played there. Brighton won the game 2–0 with [[Gary Hart (footballer)|Gary Hart]] scoring the first ever goal at the new ground. The cup final has taken place there every year since 2011. ==Eligibility== The Sussex Senior Cup is open to all men's senior clubs in the historic county of [[Sussex]] that are affiliated to the [[Sussex County Football Association]]. In 2016–17 this was 50 clubs that play in the top ten tiers of the [[English football league system]] (Premier League, English Football League, National League, National League South, Isthmian League, Southern Combination Football League Premier Division, Southern Combination Football League Division One and Southern Counties East Premier Division). ==Competition format== ===Overview=== Beginning in September, the competition proceeds as a [[knockout tournament]] throughout its duration, consisting of three rounds, then quarter-finals, semi-finals and final, usually in May. A system of byes ensures that the highest placed 14 clubs in Sussex enter the competition in the second round. For reasons of fairness to other clubs,{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} the Brighton & Hove Albion reserve team competes in the Sussex Senior Cup as, depending on season, the main squad are up to [[Football Championship]] level, many stages of the football league pyramid ahead of other teams. ===Distribution=== The tournament is organised so that 32 clubs remain by the second round. 35 of the 37 clubs in the Southern Combination League Premier Division and Division One (tiers 9 and 10 of the [[English football league system]]) and one club from the [[Southern Counties East Football League|Southern Counties East Premier Division]] (tier 9) enter in the first round. In the second round, the two highest ranked Southern Combination League Premier Division clubs from [[2015-16 in English football|2015–16]] ([[Eastbourne Town F.C.|Eastbourne Town]] and [[Peacehaven & Telscombe F.C.|Peacehaven & Telscombe]]) enter the cup, as well as [[Bognor Regis Town F.C.|Bognor Regis Town]], [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], [[Burgess Hill Town F.C.|Burgess Hill Town]], [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]], [[East Grinstead Town F.C.|East Grinstead Town]], [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]], [[Hastings United F.C.|Hastings United]], [[Horsham F.C.|Horsham]], [[Lewes F.C.|Lewes]], [[Three Bridges F.C.|Three Bridges]], [[Whitehawk F.C.|Whitehawk]] and [[Worthing F.C.|Worthing]] who all receive a bye to the second round. * Sussex-based clubs from the [[English Football League]], [[National League South]] and [[Isthmian League]] together with the two highest ranked [[Southern Combination Football League|Southern Combination Football League Premier Division]] clubs enter at the second round. * The remaining Sussex-based Southern Combination Premier Division clubs and Sussex-based clubs from Southern Combination Division One and Southern Counties East Premier Division enter at the first round. {| class="wikitable" |- ! !Clubs entering in this round !Clubs advancing from previous round |- !First round
(36 clubs) | * 18 clubs from [[Southern Combination Football League|Southern Combination Division One]] * 17 clubs from [[Southern Combination Football League|Southern Combination Premier Division]] * 1 club from [[Southern Counties East Football League|Southern Counties East Premier Division]] | |- !Second round
(32 clubs) | * 2 clubs from [[Southern Combination Football League|Southern Combination Premier Division]] * 5 clubs from [[Isthmian Football League|Isthmian League Division One South]] * 3 clubs from [[Isthmian Football League|Isthmian League Premier Division]] * 2 clubs from [[National League South]] * 1 club from [[Football League Two]] * 1 club from [[Football League Championship]] | * 18 winners from first round |- !Third round
(16 clubs) | | * 16 winners from second round |- !Fourth round
(8 clubs) | | * 8 winners from third round |- !Semi-finals
(4 clubs) | | * 4 winners from quarter-finals |- !Final
(2 clubs) | | * 2 winners from semi-finals |} ==Qualification for subsequent competitions== ===Sussex Community Shield=== The winners of the Sussex Senior Cup traditionally play the winners of the [[Sussex County Football League]] (since 2015-2016 the Southern Combination Football League) for the Sussex Community Shield (also known as the Sussex County FA Community Shield. The 2016 competition saw [[Horsham F.C.|Horsham]], the winners of the 2015-16 SCFL play [[Eastbourne Borough F.C.|Eastbourne Borough]], the winners of the 2015-16 Sussex Senior Cup.{{cite web|url=http://www.wscountytimes.co.uk/sport/more-sport/community-shield-clash-to-kick-off-sussex-fa-s-nspcc-fundraising-1-7477323|title=Community Shield clash to kick-off Sussex FA’s NSPCC fundraising|publisher=West Sussex County Times|date=14 July 2016|accessdate=6 January 2016}} Eastbourne Borough won the 2016 Sussex Community Shield 3-0.{{cite web|url=http://www.eastbourneherald.co.uk/sport/football/eastbourne-borough/impressive-borough-sink-horsham-to-land-sussex-shield-1-7509115|title=Impressive Borough sink Horsham to land Sussex Worthing | url = http://www.eastbourneherald.co.uk/sport/football/borough-lift-senior-cup-with-victory-over-worthing-1-7394372 | publisher = Eastbourne Herald | date = 2016-05-20 | accessdate = 2016-05-20}} |- |2016-17 |[[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] |[[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] |0-0, 3-0 A.E.T |[[Falmer Stadium]] |1,316 | |- |2017-18 |[[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] |[[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] |2-1 |[[Falmer Stadium]] |1,503 |{{cite web|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/16215178.Albion_U-23s_retain_Sussex_Senior_Cup_with_dramatic_win_over_Crawley/|title=Brighton and Hove Albion U-23s beat Crawley Town to win Sussex Senior Cup|date=9 May 2018|first=Amir|last=Razavi|publisher=The Argus|accessdate=11 May 2018}} |} ==Venues== [[Image:Amex Stadium Pitch panorama - geograph.org.uk - 2859086.jpg|thumb|200px|The final of the Sussex Senior Cup has been played at [[Falmer Stadium]] since 2011]] For rounds before the semi-final stage, the venue of each match is determined when the fixtures are drawn; the first club drawn in a fixture is usually the home team and matches are played at the club's home ground. The semi-finals are played at a neutral venue, usually at the Sussex FA at Culver Road in [[Lancing, West Sussex|Lancing]]. The final of the Sussex Senior Cup was held at [[Preston Park, Brighton|Preston Park]] in Brighton for the first four competitions, from 1883 to 1886. It was then held at the [[County Cricket Ground, Hove|County Cricket Ground]] in Hove for 18 editions of the cup, with the exception of the 1891 season, which was held on a league basis. In 1906 the first cup final took place to have been played at the [[Goldstone Ground]] in Hove. At the time the Goldstone Ground was the home stadium of Brighton and Hove Albion, which for some time was Sussex's only professional football club. The Goldstone Ground was known to have hosted the final of the Sussex Senior Cup a record 55 times between 1906 and 1995. Other stadiums to have hosted the Susssex Senior Cup include [[The Dripping Pan]] in Lewes (held 14 times between 1920 and 1947), The [[Newhaven F.C.|Trafalgar Ground]] in Newhaven (held twice in 1931 and 1932), [[Worthing F.C.|Woodside Road]] in Worthing (held 7 times between 1934 and 1997), [[The Saffrons]] in Eastbourne (held once in 1936), [[Horsham F.C.|Queen Street]] in Horsham (held once in 1949), [[Broadfield Stadium]] in [[Crawley]] (held twice in 1998 and 1999) and [[Priory Lane]] in [[Eastbourne]] (held 11 times between 2000 and 2010). Since 2011 the final of the Sussex Senior Cup has been played at the [[Falmer Stadium]] in [[Brighton]]. ==Records== * '''Most wins:''' 21: ** [[Worthing F.C.|Worthing]] (1893, 1904, 1908, 1914, 1920, 1923, 1927, 1929, 1935, 1940, 1945, 1946, 1947, 1952, 1957, 1959, 1961, 1975, 1977, 1978, 1999) * '''Most consecutive wins:''' 5 ** [[Bognor Regis Town F.C.|Bognor Regis Town]] (1980, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984) * '''Most appearances in a final:''' 30 ** [[Worthing F.C.|Worthing]] * '''Most consecutive appearances in a final:''' 6 ** [[Bognor Regis Town F.C.|Bognor Regis Town]] (1980, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984, 1985) * '''Most defeats in a final:''' 13 ** [[Lewes F.C.|Lewes]] * '''Biggest win:''' 7 goals: ** [[Eastbourne Town F.C.|Eastbourne]] 7-0 [[Hastings United F.C.|Hastings and St Leonards]] (1903) * '''Most goals in final:''' 11: ** [[Southwick F.C.|Southwick]] 8-3 [[Haywards Heath Town F.C.|Haywards Heath]] (1937) ==Statistics== ===Performance by club=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! ([[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]; 19 September 2016) | World champ apps = | World champ first = | World champ best = | Regional name = | Regional cup apps = | Regional cup best = | Olympic apps = | Olympic first = | Olympic medals = | Record = 4–2–0 }} '''Team North America''' was a [[Ice hockey|hockey]] team created for the [[2016 World Cup of Hockey]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.wch2016.com/north-america|title=Team North America News, Video, and Roster|website=WCH2016.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-27}} It represented players aged 23-and-under from [[Canada]] and the [[United States]]. A "Team North America" was also assembled for the [[National Hockey League All-Star Game]] from [[48th National Hockey League All-Star Game|1998]] to [[52nd National Hockey League All-Star Game|2002]], and consisted of NHL players of any age from Canada and the United States. ==2016 World Cup of Hockey== Team North America played its first pre-tournament game on September 8, 2016. They defeated [[Team Europe (ice hockey)|Team Europe]] 4–0 at the [[Centre Vidéotron|Videotron Centre]], in [[Quebec City]]. They then played 2 more pre-tournament games, defeating Team Europe 7–4, and conceding to [[Czech Republic men's national ice hockey team|Czech Republic]] 3–2. The team played only 3 official tournament games; a 4–1 win over [[Finland men's national ice hockey team|Finland]], a 4–3 loss against [[Russia men's national ice hockey team|Russia]], and a 4–3 [[Overtime (ice hockey)|overtime]] win against [[Sweden men's national ice hockey team|Sweden]]. Despite finishing in a tie with Russia for the final spot in the knockout round, Team North America did not advance as their head-to-head loss to Russia broke the tie. Team North America finished the tournament in 5th place with a record of 2–1–0. They scored 11 goals and allowed 8 for a +3 differential. ==All-time record against other nations== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" |- !width=125|Team {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = The Eilan | nickname = Eilean Bheannchair ([[Scots Gaelic]]) | image = |location = [[Newtonmore]], [[Highland (council area)|Highland]], [[Scotland]] |coordinates = {{coord|57.057567|-4.131768|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1877 | owner = [[Newtonmore Camanachd]] | operator = [[Newtonmore Camanachd]] | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[Newtonmore Camanachd]] ([[Premier Division (shinty)|Premier Division]]) (1870s–present)</center> | seating_capacity = 0 }}
'''The Eilan''', also known as "Eilean Bheannchair", in [[Scots Gaelic]], is a [[shinty]] stadium in the town of [[Newtonmore]], [[Scotland]]. It is the home of [[Newtonmore Camanachd]] and has been a shinty venue since at least 1877.
==Location==
The park is situated near a confluence between the River Calder and the [[River Spey]] on the outskirts of [[Newtonmore]]. It takes its name from Eilean Bheannchair which sits in the confluence.
==History==
Shinty is recorded as being first played at the Eilan in 1877.[http://www.newtonmore.com/want-to-know-more/history.html]
The ground was redeveloped in 1993[http://www.ambaile.org.uk/en/item/item_photograph.jsp?item_id=142182] and has hosted several junior finals, including the 2010 Sutherland Cup final. The club has still to be granted the [[Camanachd Cup]] Final.
