revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:1963 photographs]] to [[Category:1963 works]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 July 27]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{more citations needed|date=March 2016}} <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[File:The Gladiators 1963.png|thumb|250px|''The Gladiators'', John O'Gready's famous photograph of the two opposing captains, [[Norm Provan]] and [[Arthur Summons]], taken after the match.]] --> '''''The Gladiators''''' is a 1963 photograph by John O'Gready of [[Norm Provan]] and [[Arthur Summons]]. A memorable sporting image from Australia, the award winning photo later became the model for the [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSWRL premiership]] Winfield Cup trophies from 1982 to 1995 the [[National Rugby League|NRL]] trophy since 1998.
The [[New South Wales Rugby Football League season 1963#Grand Final|1963 NSW Rugby League Premiership Grand Final]] between long term rivals Western Suburbs and St George was played in a torrential downpour on Saturday, 24 August. This, combined with the fact that the centre cricket pitch area of Sydney Cricket Ground was notoriously muddy in such conditions, ensured that the players were not only saturated but also caked in mud from head to toe. At the conclusion of the hard fought match which was won by St George, the captains of the two teams, the tall [[Norm Provan]] and more diminutive Summons respectively, embraced in appreciation of each other's stoic efforts. The moment was captured by a newspaper photographer, John O'Gready, and published in the following day's ''[[Sun Herald]]''. Subsequently the image won several awards, becoming known as ''The Gladiators''. Summons has recently said that ''The Gladiators'' actually shows him complaining about the referees decision to Norm Provan.<!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[Image:Winfield Cup plus The Gladiators.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Norm Provan and Arthur Summons with the [[Winfield Cup]] trophy at the [[NSWRL season 1991#Grand Final|1991 Grand Final]]]] --> This image was the inspiration for the current premiership trophy's bronze statue.
In 2008 the Western Suburbs Magpies celebrated their centenary by inducting six inaugural members into the club's Hall of Fame. These six included Summons.<ref>{{cite web |last = westsmagpies.net |first = |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = Western Suburbs Magpies Hall of Fame |work = Wests Archives |publisher = Western Suburbs Magpies R.L.F.C |year = 2008 |url = http://www.westsmagpies.net/archives/2008/php/wests_halloffame.php |format = |doi = |accessdate = 2009-11-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081014054601/http://www.westsmagpies.net/archives/2008/php/wests_halloffame.php |archivedate = 2008-10-14 |df = }}</ref>
[[File:nrltrophy.jpg|140px|thumb|right|The Provan-Summons Trophy]] The Provan-Summons Trophy is the NRL's main prize, awarded to the team that wins the premiership. Its sculptured design is similar to the [[Winfield Cup]] trophy, which was introduced for the [[1982 NSWRFL season]]. It is a three-dimensional cast of a famous photo called The Gladiators,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Gladiators|publisher=St George Leagues Club|url=http://www.stgeorge.org.au/images/news/news_images/provan_summons_black200x330.jpg|accessdate=14 May 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080722003155/http://www.stgeorge.org.au/images/news/news_images/provan_summons_black200x330.jpg|archivedate=22 July 2008|df=}}</ref> which depicts a mud-soaked [[Norm Provan]] of [[St. George Dragons|St. George]] and [[Arthur Summons]] of [[Western Suburbs Magpies|Western Suburbs]] embracing after the [[1963 NSWRFL season]]'s Grand Final. It was not officially named the Provan-Summons Trophy until 2013, the 50th anniversary of the 1963 Grand Final.<ref>{{cite news|title=NRL Trophy named after Provan and Summons|url=http://www.nrl.com/nrl-trophy-named-after-provan-and-summons/tabid/10874/newsid/74176/default.aspx|accessdate=19 July 2014|work=nrl.com|publisher=National Rugby League|date=21 August 2013}}</ref> The trophy is awarded following each grand final to the captain of the winning club.
Each player from the premiership winning side are also awarded [[Championship ring|Premiership Rings]].
==See also== {{Portal|Rugby league|Photography}} *[[Sports photography]]

Weiboldt Construction Company{{cite news |title=New McGaw Hall to Open for First Basketball Game|first=Howard|last=Dubin|url=http://digital.library.northwestern.edu/architecture/image.php?iid=129&all=123,129,128,130,124,126,127,121,122,125|newspaper=[[The Daily Northwestern]]|location=Northwestern University|date=August 15, 1952|accessdate=November 11, 2013}} | tenants = [[Northwestern Wildcats]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])

9,500 (1952–1960) }} [[File:2016 Illinois-Northwestern game IMG 0347.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Welsh–Ryan Arena exterior]] '''Welsh–Ryan Arena''' is an 7,039-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Evanston, Illinois]], United States, near the campus of [[Northwestern University]]. It is home to four [[Northwestern Wildcats]] athletic teams: [[Northwestern Wildcats men's basketball|men's basketball]], [[Northwestern Wildcats women's basketball|women's basketball]], women's volleyball, and wrestling. It is located inside '''McGaw Memorial Hall''', to the north of [[Ryan Field (stadium)|Ryan Field]]. The building opened in 1952 as a replacement for [[Patten Gymnasium]], and was the site of the [[Final Four]] for the [[1956 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament]]. It was extensively renovated in 1983, at which time the main arena was renamed Welsh–Ryan Arena. At the conclusion of the 2016–17 basketball season, plans are to renovate and upgrade the arena as part of a $110 million project scheduled to be completed by late 2018. The renovation will displace the athletic programs that use the arena for the 2017–18 season. For years, Welsh–Ryan Arena was the smallest arena in the [[Big Ten Conference]] and the only conference facility that did not seat at least 10,000. With [[Rutgers University]] joining the conference in 2014, Welsh–Ryan became the second-smallest arena after the [[Louis Brown Athletic Center]] at Rutgers, which has a listed capacity of 8,000. Welsh–Ryan will once again become the smallest arena in the Big 10 Conference in 2018, with the listed capacity decreasing to 7,500 after renovations. ==History== McGaw Memorial Hall was built through the generosity of Northwestern University trustee and donor Foster G. McGaw, founder of the American Hospital Supply Corporation. The building, named in memory of McGaw's father, Presbyterian minister and missionary Francis A. McGaw, to house sporting events and large-scale meetings. With a [[seating capacity]] of about 13,000, McGaw Memorial Hall was one of the three largest auditoriums in the Chicago area at the time of its construction. Designed by the architectural firm of Holabird & Root & Burgee and built of reinforced concrete, McGaw Memorial Hall contained 54,000 square feet of interior space. The lighting system, consisting of 180 mercury vapor lights, was said to simulate "pure daylight." Partitions, portable bleachers, and a removable basketball floor made the building suitable for a wide variety of uses. While the intent was to provide a space large enough to hold the entire student body of Northwestern University at once during convocations and other such campus occasions, the auditorium was also used by the North Shore Music Festival and, soon after its opening, by the Second Assembly of the World Council of Churches. This event, held August 15–30, 1954, featured a convocation address by U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower. In 1983 Northwestern completed extensive renovations on the interior of the McGaw Hall. The main arena was renamed Welsh–Ryan Arena in honor of the project's principal donor, insurance magnate [[Pat Ryan (executive)|Patrick G. Ryan]], president of the Board of Trustees, and of his wife's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Welsh, Sr. The lobby was renamed Ronald J. Chinnock Lobby after real estate tycoon Ronald Chinnock. The McGaw Fieldhouse is a practice facility within the building, which in 1997 was renovated to allow practice space for basketball and volleyball. In 2007, the Brown Family Basketball Center was constructed within the McGaw Fieldhouse to include new locker rooms and team lounges for the men's and women's basketball teams, as well as offices for their respective coaching staffs. In 2016, Northwestern announced plans for a $110 million arena renovation, shuttering the facility for the 2017–18 season (the Wildcat men will play at the [[Allstate Arena]] in [[Rosemont, Illinois|Rosemont]], with the women playing out of [[Evanston Township High School]]'s Beardsley Gym that season). Capacity is expected to be reduced to around 7,500 by replacing the bleachers with chairback seats. The renovated facility will also have wider concourses, balconies behind the baskets, and suites. Before then, one of the few significant changes since the 1983 renovation had been the replacement of the arena's 1980s-vintage scoreboards with a modern video board.{{cite news|last1=Greenstein|first1=Teddy|title=Northwestern's Welsh–Ryan Arena to receive long-overdue overhaul|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/college/ct-northwestern-welsh-ryan-renovation-20160613-column.html|accessdate=22 December 2016|agency=Chicago Tribune|date=13 June 2016}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://nusports.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/nw-m-baskbl-welsh-arena.html Welsh–Ryan Arena (from NUSports.com)] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = [[NCAA]] [[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Championship|Men's Division I]]

'''Winger''', in the [[Ice hockey|game of ice hockey]], is a [[forward (ice hockey)|forward]] position of a player whose primary zone of play on the ice is along the outer playing area. They typically work by [[Flanking maneuver|flank]]ing the [[centre (ice hockey)|centre]] forward. Originally the name was given to forward players who went up and down the sides of the rink. Nowadays, there are different types of wingers in the game — out-and-out goal scorers, checkers who disrupt the opponents, and forwards who work along the boards and in the corners. They tend to be bigger than centreman and smaller than defenseman.
This position is commonly referred to by the side of the rink that the winger normally takes, i.e. "left wing" or "right wing."
== Defensive zone play == [[File:Defensive Winger (Ice hockey).PNG|thumb|right|Typical winger positioning in the defensive zone.]]
The wingers' responsibilities in the [[hockey rink#Zones|defensive zone]] include the following: *getting open for a pass from their teammates *intercepting a pass to the opposing [[defenceman]] *attacking the opposing defencemen when they have the puck
Wingers should typically not: *play deep in their defensive zone *help out their teammates along the boards *
== Offensive zone play == Wingers should be playing high in the zone, and always be vigilant for a breakout pass or a chance to chip the puck [[Offside (ice hockey)|past the blue line]]. When wingers receive a pass along the boards, they can exercise a number of options:
*Bank the puck off the boards or glass to get it out of the zone *Redirect or softly pass the puck to a rushing forward *Shoot the puck out to the centre line to another forward who can either set up an attack, or dump the puck into the offensive zone to summon a line change *Carry the puck themselves into the offensive zone to attempt a [[Breakaway (ice hockey)|breakaway]] or an odd man rush
==Backchecking== Wingers are usually the last players to [[checking (ice hockey)|backcheck]] out of the offensive zone. On the backcheck, it is essential that they cover the last free opposing player rushing in. Once the puck is controlled by the opposing team in the defensive zone, however, wingers are responsible for covering the defenceman on their side of the ice.
==Face-offs== Prior to the puck being dropped for a [[face-off]], players other than those taking the face-off must not make any physical contact with players on the opposite team, nor enter the face-off circle (where marked). After the puck is dropped, it is essential for wingers to engage the opposing players to prevent them from obtaining possession of the puck.
Once a team has established control of the puck, wingers can set themselves up into an appropriate position.
Some wingers are also employed to handle faceoffs.<ref>[http://www.dallasnews.com/sports/dallas-stars/headlines/20131018-heika-stars-jamie-benn-taking-skills-learned-while-playing-center-into-new-lw-role.ece Heika: Faceoff skills learned playing center paying dividends for Stars' Jamie Benn in new position]</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} [[Image:2005 WSOP gold bracelet.jpg|thumb|300px|
Non-Main Event gold bracelets given to the event winners during the [[2005 World Series of Poker]]
]] The '''World Series of Poker (WSOP) bracelet''' is considered the most coveted non-monetary prize a [[poker]] player can win. Since 1976, a bracelet has been awarded to the winner of every event at the annual [[World Series of Poker|WSOP]]. Even if the victory occurred before 1976, WSOP championships are now counted as "bracelets". During the first years of the WSOP only a handful of bracelets were awarded each year. In 1990, there were only 14 bracelet events. By 2000, that number increased to 24. As the popularity of poker has increased during the 2000s, the number of events has likewise increased. In 2011, 58 bracelets were awarded at the WSOP, seven at the [[World Series of Poker Europe]] (WSOPE), and one to the WSOP National Circuit Champion.{{cite web|url=http://www.wsop.com/news/2011/May/3329/SAM-BARNHART-WINS-INAUGURAL-WSOP-CIRCUIT-NATIONAL-CHAMPIONSHIP.html|title=Sam Barnhart Wins Inaugural WSOP Circuit National Championship|accessdate=June 5, 2011|date=May 29, 2001|publisher=Caesars Interactive Entertainment, Inc.|work=WSOP.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110602153754/http://www.wsop.com/news/2011/May/3329/SAM-BARNHART-WINS-INAUGURAL-WSOP-CIRCUIT-NATIONAL-CHAMPIONSHIP.html|archivedate=June 2, 2011|df=mdy-all}} This brought the total number of bracelets awarded up to 959. Five additional bracelets were awarded for the first time in April 2013 at the inaugural World Series of Poker Asia-Pacific (WSOP APAC) in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]].{{cite press release |url=http://www.wsop.com/news/2012/May/3761/WSOP-ANNOUNCES-PARTNERSHIP-WITH-CROWN-FOR-APRIL-2013-EVENT-IN-MELBOURNE-AUSTRALIA.html |title=WSOP Announces Partnership With Crown for April 2013 Event in Melbourne, Australia |publisher=World Series of Poker |date=April 30, 2012 |accessdate=May 10, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504203339/http://www.wsop.com/news/2012/May/3761/WSOP-ANNOUNCES-PARTNERSHIP-WITH-CROWN-FOR-APRIL-2013-EVENT-IN-MELBOURNE-AUSTRALIA.html |archivedate=May 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}. In 2017, 74 for bracelets were awarded at the WSOP and an additional 11 will be awarded at the WSOPE in Czech Republic. After the conclusion of the [[2014 World Series of Poker Asia Pacific|2014 WSOP APAC]], there have been 1083 bracelets awarded, 500 of which were won by 170 players who have won at least two bracelets, with all of the other bracelets being won by one-time winners. This includes (up to this point) 17 [[List of World Series of Poker Main Event champions|Main Event winners]]: [[Hal Fowler]], [[Bill Smith (poker player)|Bill Smith]], [[Mansour Matloubi]], [[Brad Daugherty (poker player)|Brad Daugherty]], [[Jim Bechtel]], [[Russ Hamilton]], [[Noel Furlong]], [[Robert Varkonyi]], [[Chris Moneymaker]], [[Greg Raymer]], [[Joe Hachem]], [[Jamie Gold]], [[Jerry Yang (poker player)|Jerry Yang]], [[Peter Eastgate]], [[Pius Heinz]], [[Ryan Riess]] and [[Martin Jacobson]]. Since Chris Moneymaker won the 2003 Main Event, (through the completion of Event {{abbr|No.|number}} 74 in 2017) only three players have won and followed it up with a win in another bracelet event, [[Jonathan Duhamel]], [[Joe Cada]] and [[Joe McKeehen]] . ==Bracelet description== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = Main Event Championship Bracelets | image1 = 2005 WSOP Championship bracelet.jpg | width1 = 175 | caption1 = [[2005 World Series of Poker]] Championship Bracelet
Made of [[platinum]] & diamonds
Winner: [[Joe Hachem]] | image2 = 2006 WSOP Championship Bracelet.jpg | width2 = 175 | caption2 = [[2006 World Series of Poker]] Championship bracelet
Made of white and yellow gold, diamonds, [[ruby|rubies]] and [[sapphire]]s
Winner: [[Jamie Gold]] | image3 = Wsop2007.jpg | width3 = 175 | caption3 = [[2007 World Series of Poker]] Championship Bracelet
Made of 136 grams of white gold, and 120 diamonds.
Winner: [[Jerry Yang (poker player)|Jerry Yang]] }} The 1976 bracelet looked "like gold nuggets kind of hammered flat". The bracelet in 1976 cost approximately $500. In the 1980s, [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] jeweler Mordechai Yerushalmi became the exclusive manufacturer of WSOP bracelets until Harrah's Entertainment bought the rights to the WSOP in 2004. According to 2003 WSOP Champion [[Chris Moneymaker]], the design of the bracelet remained relatively unchanged under Yerushalmi.ESPN's coverage of the 2007 World Series of Poker Episode 13 In 2005, Gold and Diamond International based in Memphis, TN won the bid from Harrah's Entertainment to manufacture the 2005 World Series of Poker bracelets. The company also manufactures the WSOP circuit rings.CardPlayer Magazine In 2006, Frederick Goldman, Inc. made the WSOP bracelets while luxury watch maker Corum introduced some commemorative watches as part of the prize package.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/tourney/updates.asp?tid=3461&grid=309|title=Limit Hold'em (Event 34)|work=World Series of Poker|publisher=Harrah's Entertainment|accessdate=June 15, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pokerpages.com/tournament/result20309.htm|title=39th World Series of Poker 2008|work=Poker Tournament Results|publisher=PokerPages|accessdate=June 14, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314054501/http://www.pokerpages.com/tournament/result20309.htm|archivedate=March 14, 2009|df=mdy-all}} In 2006, the Champion's bracelet had 259 stones including 7.2 carats (1.4 g) of diamonds, 120 grams of white and yellow gold. It also used rubies to represent the heart and diamond suits, a sapphire to represent the spade and three black diamonds to represent the clubs. In 2007, Corum became the official bracelet manufacturer for the WSOP. Some of the 2007 World Series of Poker champions received both a watch and a bracelet from Corum. Corum designed four variations for the 2007 World Series of Poker Bracelets. The standard version that is presented to 53 winners features 53 diamonds.[http://www.globeinvestor.com/servlet/story/BWIRE.20070605.20070605006220/GIStory CORUM Introduces New World Series of Poker(R) Bracelets] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091211213804/http://www.globeinvestor.com/servlet/story/BWIRE.20070605.20070605006220/GIStory |date=December 11, 2009 }} June 5, 2007. ''GlobalInvestor'' Accessed July 30, 2007 The Ladies World Champion receives a bracelet that is adorned with four black diamonds, two rubies and 87 blue sapphires.Press Release. [http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/news/varchive.asp?aid=1021 Poker Academy Student Bests Largest-Ever Field To Become 2007 World Series of Poker Ladies Champion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711023153/http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/news/varchive.asp?aid=1021 |date=July 11, 2007 }} June 13, 2007. ''WorldSeriesofPoker.com'' Accessed July 7, 2007 The $50,000 HORSE Champion Bracelet has 91 black diamonds and two rubies.Press Release.[http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/news/varchive.asp?aid=824 CORUM Introduces New World Series of Poker Bracelets; Elegant Design Features 18 Carat Gold, Precious Gems] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007133009/http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/news/varchive.asp?aid=824 |date=October 7, 2007 }} June 5, 2007. ''WorldSeriesofPoker.com'' Accessed July 7, 2007 The World Series of Poker Main Event Bracelet has 120 diamonds on 136 grams of 18 carat (75 percent) white gold. The value of the 2007 bracelets have not been released, but the typical price of a Corum watch ranges from $1,500–$30,000+.[http://www.nextag.com/corum-watch-men/search-html Corum pricelist per Next Tag] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927010004/http://www.nextag.com/corum-watch-men/search-html |date=September 27, 2007 }} Accessed July 30, 2007 In 2008, the Main Event Bracelet had 291 diamonds, totalling 2.81 carats set in 168 grams of 18kt white gold. The other 54 event bracelets consisted of 55 diamonds, totalling 0.25 carats set in 80 grams of 14kt yellow gold.[http://www.vialuxe.com/News/Corum-Watches-Corum-2008-World-Series-of-Poker-Bracelets/1783,28977 Corum 2008 World Series of Poker Bracelets – ViaLuxe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223015311/http://www.vialuxe.com/News/Corum-Watches-Corum-2008-World-Series-of-Poker-Bracelets/1783,28977 |date=February 23, 2010 }} In 2010, an Australian-based company OnTilt Designs Pty Ltd won a multi-year contract to become the official bracelet manufacturer for the WSOP. OnTilt jewelers decided that the 2010 bracelet design would return to the tradition of the 1970s and 1980s where the bracelet was a heavy piece of unadorned metal. American jewelry designer [[Steve Soffa]] was chosen to design and manufacture the entire set of bracelets.{{cite web | url=http://www.pokernewsdaily.com/wsop-bracelet-designer-steve-soffa-interview-11316/ | title=WSOP Bracelet Designer Steve Soffa Interview | publisher=Poker News Daily | date=14 May 2010 | accessdate=29 April 2014 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429193034/http://www.pokernewsdaily.com/wsop-bracelet-designer-steve-soffa-interview-11316/ | archivedate=April 29, 2014 | df=mdy-all }} The goal was to create a bracelet that somebody would actually want to wear every day. In 2011, OnTilt has also been chosen to manufacture the [[World Series of Poker Circuit events|WSOP Circuit]] rings. In 2012, Jason Arasheben, famed jewelry designer and owner of Jason of Beverly Hills was chosen as the official bracelet manufacturer of the WSOP. Arasheben had designed the championship rings for the 2009 and 2010 Los Angeles Lakers and the 2011 Green Bay Packers, among others. The Main Event bracelet will feature each suit in the deck in either rubies or black diamonds. In terms of sheer mass, it weighs in at over 160 grams of 14 karat gold and over 35 carats of flawless diamonds.{{cite web |url=http://www.bluff.com/news/wsop-reveals-new-bracelet-design-by-jason-of-beverly-hills-26967/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140706124628/http://www.bluff.com/news/wsop-reveals-new-bracelet-design-by-jason-of-beverly-hills-26967/ |archivedate=July 6, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} A special platinum bracelet was awarded at the 2012 WSOP to the winner of The [[Big One for One Drop]], Antonio Esfandiari. The event was a $1 million buy-in tournament created as a fundraiser for the [[One Drop Foundation]], a charity established by [[Cirque du Soleil]] founder [[Guy Laliberté]].{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/poker/story/_/id/7804846/world-series-poker-offer-1-million-buy-tournament |title=WSOP to offer $1 million buy-in |author=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=April 12, 2012 |accessdate=April 13, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413123408/http://espn.go.com/poker/story/_/id/7804846/world-series-poker-offer-1-million-buy-tournament |archivedate=April 13, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ==Prestige== At first, the bracelets did not have much prestige. Ten-time bracelet winner [[Doyle Brunson]] said that his first bracelet "didn't mean anything" to him and that he did not even pick up two of them. Some professional poker players believe that there are two types of poker players; those who have won a bracelet and those who have not. Those who have belong to an exclusive club. "It's impossible to overstate the value of a World Series of Poker gold bracelet to anyone who takes the game seriously," stated World Series of Poker Commissioner [[Jeffrey Pollack]] during the 2006 bracelet unveiling. "It is the equivalent of winning the [[Stanley Cup]] in [[ice hockey|hockey]] or the [[Vince Lombardi Trophy|Lombardi Trophy]] in [[American football]]."Burton, Earl. [http://www.pokernews.com/news/2006/6/world-series-poker-bracelet.htm 2006 World Series of Poker Bracelet Unveiled]. June 7, 2006. ''Pokernews.com'' Accessed July 30, 2007 Many professional poker players desire the recognition that is associated with the bracelet. Former [[Celebrity Poker Showdown]] host and poker star [[Phil Gordon]] said, "I want that bracelet more than anything."[http://www.pokerlistings.com/phil-gordons-quest-for-a-wsop-bracelet-continues-734 Phil Gordon's Quest for a WSOP Bracelet Continues] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927193038/http://www.pokerlistings.com/phil-gordons-quest-for-a-wsop-bracelet-continues-734 |date=September 27, 2007 }}. (June 10, 2005). ''Pokerlistings.com''. [[Freddy Deeb]] said that he did not appreciate his first bracelet because he did not recognize what it meant. He said his 2007 bracelet, however, "means everything to me".Press Release. [http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/news/varchive.asp?aid=1346 Freddy Deeb Wins $50,000 HORSE Championship at World Series of Poker Title Establishes Deeb as World's Best All-Around Player] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007140018/http://www.worldseriesofpoker.com/news/varchive.asp?aid=1346 |date=October 7, 2007 }} June 29, 2007. ''WorldSeriesOfPoker.com'' Accessed July 30, 2007 [[Jennifer Tilly]] says that winning her 2005 Women's Championship bracelet was "better than an [[Academy Award|Oscar]]".ESPN's Coverage of the 2007 World Series of Poker, Episode 2 When the [[World Poker Tour]] decided to offer a prize to its event champions, they decided to present them with [[World Poker Tour bracelet|WPT Bracelets.]] In so doing, WPT Founder, President and CEO Steve Lipscomb said, "The championship bracelet has become synonymous with poker as a symbol of achievement and respect, and we are honored to continue the tradition that [[Benny Binion]] [the founder of the WSOP] began over 30 years ago."{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS132757+08-Apr-2008+BW20080408|title=Six Seasons of Champions to Receive WPT Championship Bracelet|date=April 8, 2008|work=Reuters|accessdate=February 11, 2009}} ==History== Bracelets have not always been awarded for winning events. In 1970, the first WSOP Champion received nothing but a silver cup and whatever cash he won during the event.The first WSOP was not a freeze out tournament, but rather a collection of the top players playing against one another and the eventual winner was determined by a vote. [http://www.pokerplayerpress.com/Gallery-JohnnyMoss.html Johnny Moss Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811165953/http://www.pokerplayerpress.com/Gallery-JohnnyMoss.html |date=August 11, 2007 }} ''PokerPlayerPress.com'' From 1971–1974, according to Becky Behnen (the daughter of WSOP founder [[Benny Binion]]), the winner received an undescribed "corny trophy".Associated Press [http://www.abqtrib.com/news/2006/jul/28/pokers-glory-is-about-the-bracelet-not-the-money/?printer=1/ Poker's glory is about the bracelet, not the money] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422062532/http://www.abqtrib.com/news/2006/jul/28/pokers-glory-is-about-the-bracelet-not-the-money/?printer=1%2F |date=April 22, 2009 }} ''Albuquerque Tribune''. (July 28, 2006). In 1975, the winners received a sterling plate. The following year, 1976, the WSOP started the tradition of issuing bracelets to the event winners. In 1980 and 1981, one did not have to win a WSOP event to win a gold bracelet. In 1980 and 1981, H.D. "Oklahoma Johny" Hale and [[Chip Reese]] received a gold bracelet for being the "Best All Around Player" at the WSOP, respectively."Oklahoma Johnny" Hale.[http://gaming.unlv.edu/WSOP/Hale.pdf "Oklahoma Johnny" Hale.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208025543/http://gaming.unlv.edu/WSOP/Hale.pdf |date=December 8, 2006 }} '''The Life and Times of a Gentleman Gambler.''' Las Vegas: Poker Plus Publications, 1999. 127–132. Accessed July 12, 2007] These bracelets, however, are not considered in the count of WSOP championship bracelets. In 2007, [[Thomas Bihl]] became the first person to ever win a WSOP bracelet outside [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], Nevada. Bihl won the £2,500 World Championship H.O.R.S.E. at the [[World Series of Poker Europe]] in London, England.{{cite web|url=http://www.pokerlistings.com/poker-player-interviews/wsop/2007/send-the-bills-to-bihl-thomas-bihl-wins-wsope-event-1|title=Send the bills to Bihl! – Thomas Bihl wins WSOPE Event 1|work=Poker Listing|date=August 7, 2007|accessdate=June 15, 2009|last=Crowson|first=Authur|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080717001619/http://www.pokerlistings.com/poker-player-interviews/wsop/2007/send-the-bills-to-bihl-thomas-bihl-wins-wsope-event-1|archivedate=July 17, 2008|df=mdy-all}} Days later, [[Annette Obrestad]] became the youngest player to ever win a WSOP bracelet at 18 years, 364 days, also becoming the first woman to win a World Series Main Event (WSOPE).{{cite web|url=http://www.pokernews.com/news/2007/09/wsope-event-3-final-table-annette-obrestad-wins.htm|work=Pokernews.com|title=£10,000 NLHE, Final Table: Annette Obrestad Makes History|accessdate=May 9, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530144034/http://www.pokernews.com/news/2007/09/wsope-event-3-final-table-annette-obrestad-wins.htm|archivedate=May 30, 2009|df=mdy-all}} Caesars Entertainment (known until 2010 as Harrah's Entertainment), the owner of the WSOP, considers the WSOP Europe bracelet to be the same in prestige as those awarded every year in Las Vegas. In 2008, [[Jesper Hougaard]] became the first person to have won both a WSOP and WSOPE bracelet. In 2011, a World Series of Poker bracelet was awarded for the first time to the [[World Series of Poker Circuit events|WSOP Circuit National Championship]] winner in the 100-qualifier event from May 27–29.{{cite web|url=http://www.wsop.com/tourney/tourneydetails.asp?groupID=812|title=$1,000,000 WSOP Circuit NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP|accessdate=June 5, 2011|date=May 29, 2001|publisher=Caesars |df=mdy-all }} Starting in 2013, bracelets are also awarded in [[Australia]] at the World Series of Poker Asia-Pacific, held at [[Crown Casino and Entertainment Complex|Crown Melbourne]]. ==Bracelet legacy== Of the three top WSOP bracelet winners, only [[Johnny Chan (poker player)|Johnny Chan]] still has them all. He keeps them locked in a vault because they are worth, according to him, "millions". Brunson did not pick up two of his. Fifteen-time bracelet winner [[Phil Hellmuth]] gave away ten of his. "To me," Hellmuth said, "the bracelets have always been a really huge deal, to me more than the other guys, because I knew that they represented history." Three-time WSOP Bracelet winner [[Hamid Dastmalchi]] and six-time winner [[Ted Forrest]] had been playing for four days non-stop at [[the Mirage]] when Hamid started to complain about the 1992 Main Event Championship Bracelet he received. Bitter about a dispute with the [[Binion's Horseshoe]], the owners of the WSOP at the time, Hamid told the table that the Binion's "say it's worth $5,000, but I'd take $1,500 for it." To which Forrest responded "Sold" and immediately tossed Hamid $1,500 in chips. Dastmalchi mailed Forrest his bracelet.{{cite web|url=http://www.pokernewsdaily.com/ted-forrest-141/|title=Ted Forrest|work=Player Profiile|publisher=Poker News Daily|accessdate=June 20, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223231015/http://www.pokernewsdaily.com/ted-forrest-141/|archivedate=February 23, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fulltiltpoker.com/poker-blog/2009/06/767_2009_wsop_25_ghost_series_3_39_champions_part_iii.php|title=#767 – 2009 WSOP No. 25 – Ghost Series No. 3 – 39 Champions, Part III|last=Wilson|first=Craig|date=June 9, 2009|accessdate=June 20, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090612052656/http://www.fulltiltpoker.com/poker-blog/2009/06/767_2009_wsop_25_ghost_series_3_39_champions_part_iii.php|archivedate=June 12, 2009|df=mdy-all}} Ted Forrest also reported that three of his five bracelets have been stolen over the years, and that he gave his daughter one.Administrator [http://www.ixgames.com/ted_forrest/ Ted Forrest Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928141633/http://www.ixgames.com/ted_forrest/ |date=September 28, 2007 }} ''IXGames'' Accessed July 30, 2007 In November 2010, [[Peter Eastgate]] put his main event bracelet up for auction on [[eBay]] with a starting bid of $16,000. It eventually sold for $147,500{{cite web|url=http://poker-on-line.com/news/1011/peter-eastgate-2008-wsop-bracelet-sold.html|title=Peter Eastgate WSOP Bracelet Sold on ebay for $147,500|website=poker-on-line.com|accessdate=August 9, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170810012226/http://poker-on-line.com/news/1011/peter-eastgate-2008-wsop-bracelet-sold.html|archivedate=August 10, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pokernewsdaily.com/peter-eastgate-auctions-wsop-main-event-bracelet-for-147500-16980/|title=Peter Eastgate Auctions WSOP Main Event Bracelet for $147,500|publisher=|accessdate=August 9, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705121833/https://www.pokernewsdaily.com/peter-eastgate-auctions-wsop-main-event-bracelet-for-147500-16980/|archivedate=July 5, 2017|df=mdy-all}} and this money was donated to [[UNICEF]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pokernews.com/news/2010/11/the-nightly-turbo-peter-eastgate-auctions-of-wsop-bracelet-a-9333.htm|title=The Nightly Turbo: Peter Eastgate Auctions off WSOP Bracelet, APT Macau Crowns Winner, and More|publisher=|accessdate=August 9, 2017}} ==Multiple bracelet winners== {{main|World Series of Poker multiple bracelet winners}} The top bracelet winners are as follows: {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Player ! class="unsortable" | Wins during decade |- |align=center|1970s |align=center|7 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Johnny Moss]] |'''1970''', '''1971''' (2), '''1974''', 1975, 1976, 1979 |- |align=center|1980s |align=center|4 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Stu Ungar]] |'''1980''', '''1981''' (2), 1983 |- |align=center|1990s |align=center|5 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Phil Hellmuth]] |1992, 1993 (3), 1997 |- |align=center|2000s |align=center|7 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Phil Ivey]] |2000, 2002 (3), 2005, 2009 (2) |- |rowspan=8 align=center|2010s |rowspan=8 align=center|4 |{{flagicon|GER}} [[George Danzer]] |2014 (3), 2016 |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Jason Mercier]] |2011, 2015, 2016 (2) |- |{{flagicon|GER}} [[Dominik Nitsche]] |2012, 2014 (2), 2017 |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Brian Rast]] |2011 (2), 2016, 2018 |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Mizrachi]] |2010, 2011 [E], 2012, 2018 |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Phil Hellmuth]] |2012, 2012 [E], 2015, 2018 |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Shaun Deeb]] |2015, 2016, 2018 (2) |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Brian Hastings (poker player)|Brian Hastings]] |2012, 2015 (2), 2018 |} (bold = won [[List of World Series of Poker Main Event champions#World Series of Poker Main Event|Main Event]]) [[Johnny Moss]], with a win at the [[1971 World Series of Poker|1971 WSOP]], became the first person to have won multiple lifetime WSOP "bracelets" (as mentioned above, the first actual bracelet was given in 1976). Moss also was the first person to win five lifetime WSOP bracelets, with a win at the [[1975 World Series of Poker|1975 WSOP]]. [[Johnny Chan (poker player)|Johnny Chan]], with a win in Event No. 25 at the [[2005 World Series of Poker]], became the first person to win 10 lifetime WSOP bracelets, just a few days before [[Doyle Brunson]] won his 10th bracelet in Event No. 31 of that same WSOP. The first person to win two bracelets in the same WSOP was Johnny Moss at the [[1971 World Series of Poker|1971 WSOP]]. The first person to win three bracelets in the same WSOP was [[Puggy Pearson|Walter "Puggy" Pearson]], at the [[1973 World Series of Poker|1973 WSOP]]. As of the start of the 2016 WSOP, only five other players have won three bracelets in a single WSOP. [[Bill Boyd (poker player)|Bill Boyd]] and Doyle Brunson are the only players to have won bracelets in four consecutive years (Boyd from 1971 to 1974, and Brunson from 1976 to 1979). ==WSOP rings== In 2005, the WSOP started hosting [[World Series of Poker Circuit events|Circuit Events]] at many of their casinos around the country. In order to differentiate these events and to ensure the prestige of the WSOP Bracelet, the circuit events present a ring to the winners. In 2011, the WSOP awarded a bracelet to the winner of the Circuit Event National Championship. The Circuit Event National Championship was an invitation only event that used the standings of players from the various circuit events in determining who was invited. ==Circuit National Championship== Starting with the [[2011 World Series of Poker Circuit|2011 WSOP Circuit]], the Circuit National Championship was held as a closed event for participants of various circuit events. Starting in [[2011–12 World Series of Poker Circuit|2012]], qualification for the Circuit National Championship was significantly changed. A total of 100 players now receive automatic seats in the National Championship. The winners of each Circuit main event and the highest point earner at each circuit stop receive seats, with the remaining automatic seats filled by the top points earners throughout the Circuit season who are not already qualified. Additionally, the top 100 players in the "WSOP World Rankings", a points race determined on results in open events of the previous two WSOPs, are eligible to enter. The Circuit qualifiers play the National Championship on a freeroll, while the WSOP World Rankings qualifiers must pay a $10,000 buy-in.
